How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Now how many kangaroos he has?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: 9<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write an if/else statement that answers the question below. He found old bread in the breadbox and forgot a moldy lefthanded leftover in his carpet.<n>### Response:<n><n>### Input<n>A: There are three types of food: meat, vegetables, and fruit.<n><n>Output: There are 8 types of food.<n><n>### Reason<n>A: Meat, 2 types, beef and chicken.<n><n>Vegetables: 3 types, green, yellow, and orange.<n><n>Fruit: 1 type, watermelon.<n><n>### Input (11 characters of 32)<n><n>### Output (6 characters of 32):<n><n>    There are 7 types of food.<n>### Reason (33 characters of 32 - 13):<n>    meat. chicken. beef.<n>      fruit waterman.<n>      green. yellow. orange.<n><n>### What is the output of the following pseudo-code?<n>```<n>countDown (n)<n>```<n><n>### What happens if the input is: countDown (7)<n>### Demonstatation:<n>Input: countDown (7)\<n><n>Output: n >= 8<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:  <n>N = 4<n><n>CountDown (n):<n><n>for i = n to n - 1 do<n>    i = i - 1<n>    countDown(i)<n><n>Print<n>countdown = 4<n>for i = 4 to 1 do<n>    countdown = countdown - 1<n>print<n>```<n>### Input:<n>The forgotten leftover had gotten quite old he found it covered with mold.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>A: the what of the forgotten left left had been left had been covered in covered in mold.<n><n>C: the forgotten left had been covered in mold. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. Choices:  A: full stomach B: getting full C: gaining weight D: sick E: satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The correct answer is D.<n><n>### Input<n>You are trying to go on a hike with just enough food for you and your partner. If you are only going to stop every hour to eat, what can you eat that weighs 8.3 pounds if it lasts for up to 9 hours and gives you 1500 calories?<n><n>### Response<n><n>This is not a multiple choice question.  You must provide an explanation for your answer.<n><n>### Response Explanation<n><n>```python<n>import food_weight<n><n># Example solution<n><n>answer = 1386<n>calories = 475<n><n>total_weight = calories / 1500 * food_weight.get_calories_for_lb(8.2)<n><n>if total_weight >= food_weight.get(meals_per_day):<n>    answer = food_weight.get<n><n>else:<n>    answer = "Not enough food"<n><n>if total_weigh <= food_weight.get:<n>    answer = food<n>```<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>What's the sum of a multiple of 18 and a multiple of 24?<n><n>### Instructor Solution<n><n>```python<n>def solution(n: int) -> int:<n>    answer = 0<n>    for x in range(18, 33):<n>        answer += (answer + 1) % n<n>    return answer % n<n>```

What might the cops do to him? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		The Cops will pick "A" A: go to jail<n>B: go to prison<n>C: beat him up<n>D: get arrested<n>E: die<n><n>## Example 1:<n>This example is marked as `solved`, means that it is correct, not only code is correct, but also the solution is correct and easy to implement in the code.<n><n>If you have any suggestions on the description please let me know asap.<n><n>The answer is:<n><n>input:Mary had 89 stickners. She used 3 large stingers on the front page of journal and 7 stickners each to 6 other page of journal. How much stickners does Mary have remaining? Answer: 44.<n><n>There is 3 way we can solve: 1* 89 2* 7 3* 7 *3 + *89**7 = 7^2*89 + *89**49 = 49*271 + *89**98 = 49 * 98 + *89**196 = 49 * (181) + *298**196 = (342) + *196**196 =820<n><n>## Example 2:<n>This example is not marked as `solved` yet, it has some incorrect solution, please help me point them out and I will mark as correct.<n><n>If you think that this is correct, please let me know.<n><n>The answer to this question should be 1, not 4, since Mary saved 42+67=115 (remaindering) on the back page of her journal instead of just the front and not even every other page.<n>![Mary-2](Mary-2.png)<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where would you put a folding chair if you do not plan to use it and you do not have any large doors in your house? Choices:  A: roof B: school C: beach D: closet E: garage<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Answer: E. Garage<n><n><n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: being entertained D: math E: meet<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```<n>Expected Answer : sit<n>```<n><n>Input:Ted is doing his math paper, on which he is spending 18 minutes.  In addition, he needs to find his pencil, walk to the bathroom and use the restroom.  Finally, he needs to re-sharpen his pencil.  He is doing this in parallel and he believes the whole process will take no longer than 60 minutes.  How much time does Ted spend on math problems?<n><n>### Expected Answer:  60 - 15 = 45 minutes<n><n>### Response<n><n>```<n>Explanation- We used a system that can generate the solution within few clicks, where we can add the steps and parameters.<n>Then, we inputted the formula for finding the sum of 45 minutes, where we can insert the answer and the parameters. In this way, we answered the questions that asked us to find the answer of a question. Furthermore, The system is designed to help the user in finding the answers of questions.<n><n>```<n>### Input: Write a program that prints HelloWorld.<n><n>### Explanation- First, we declared an empty string and we are setting variable to the empty string.<n><n>Then, we are checking for the length. And we are printing the variable and we got the result for the question<n><n><n><n>### Input :Write a program that shows the following:  1 * 2 = 2, 2 + 2 = 4, 3 * 3 = 9, 2 + 3 = 5, 3 * 4 = 12, and 7 / 2 = 3.5<n><n>### Explation-  Write a programme, which is a logical sequence of operations to be performed by the machine.<n>Here in this example input will be of the form 1 * 2 =,2 + 2 = and so on. <n><n>In next line we will have the answer to that 1.2.3.. In the 4th line it will be 1.3.4 and so on and in the next 2 lines we will print our 2 numbers 2 and 3. So here at the end of the programme we will have the final answers to these questions.<n><n><n>### Response Write your Java program that reads a matrix

Then answer the question that follows.<n><n>### Input 4:<n><n>### Demo 4:<n>Input: This is just a little number. That little number has many many big numbers inside of it. What is that little number inside the big number?<n>Answer:  The number 64<n><n>### Input5:<n><n>### Instructs: Write a program that will show the below instructions on the screen. Then write a program that will replace Input 5 with the answer.<n><n>### Demo5:<n>Input: 711 + 2 + 3. Answer: 898<n><n>### Instucture: Write code.<n><n>### A:<n><n>```vb<n>i=5<n>if i=5 then<n>  "Do this"<n>```<n><n>### B:<n><n>```vb <n><n>i=5<n>x=""<n>if i=5 <n>  then<n>  "Do that" else<n>  "Do this""<n><n>```<n><n>## Solution 1<n><n>```vb<n>a:=1<n>b:=5<n><n>while b>1 do<n>  print "a=" a " b=" b<n>  a=a+1<n>  b=b-1<n>end while<n><n><n>a:=5<n>b:=2<n><n>while b>0 do<n>  print a<n>  b=b+1<n>  a=a-1<n>end while```<n><n>## #Solution 2 <n><n>```vb<n><n>a:=0<n>i:=1<n>for<n>  do<n>    if (a = i-1 then <n>    "If a=i-1, do this;"<n>   else "else do this;"<n>do a:="a+1"<n>i:="a+1 <n><n>```<n><n><n>## Blog<n><n>[Learn to Program Book](https://web.cs.duke.edu/courses/fall11/cis342/lever/lever.pdf)<n><n>[CSharp Corner Forum](http://www.csharpcorner.com/forums/thread/31060/c-is-a-good-choice-for-gaming-software)

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>A - The person would feel angry because he or she would be robbed.<n><n>### Input<n>You're going to travel to California for the summer.  Your friend offers you half of her gas money.  The cost of gas to California is $3.50 per gallon.  You are going to rent a car in Los Angeles to drive back to your home in Washington state. If you rent the car for one week and you give your friend half of her gas money you have enough money for one last tank of gas on Monday. How much gas can you buy for $10?<n>Answer: $410<n><n>### Explanation<n>The gas cost in this problem is $3.5. After we have given $1.75 to our friend, we have $1.75 left as gas. The gas of 1st tank of gas cost is 3.5 times 1st gas, the cost is 3 times of 1st gas. The gas of $410 is 3 times of $10 gas, the gas is $10 +.3 gas.<n>The answer is the gas of $417.25 or $417.50.<n><n>### Examples<n>Irrational (non-fraudulent) examples:<n><n>Examples 1<n>A person would probably feel unhappy if his or her money was stolen, the person might feel very upset that he or she had done that.<n><n>In the problem of 16+12=33, he or she would feel cross with the person who counted the question, or that would feel unhappy because he or she would not be counting anymore<n><n>### Impossibilities (fraudulent) Examples<n>Example 1) $2+1=4<n><n>$2+1$<n><n>Ans:(fraudulent) 4)<n><n>### Feedback<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E<n><n>1. If you think a surface of earth is the correct answer; that area of the earth with no grass, also known as a rest area, does not have enough space for your roadside stand.<n><n>2. If you think a rest area is the correct answer; you cannot have the rest area and the roadside stand in the same area because a rest area cannot provide enough space for a roadside stand.<n> <n>3. If you think a supermarket is the correct answer; a roadside stand is a temporary place, not a permanent business like a supermarket therefore the right choice is a garden.<n><n>4. If you think a state park is the correct answer; the roadside stand is a permanent business, but not a state park, therefore the correct answer is a garden.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:How is someone who loves their TV likely to feel about their remote? Choices:  A: attached B: nostalgic C: companionable D: likely E: close<n><n>### Response:		 <n>  Attached means they are highly attached to the remote, therefore they are very close to it.<n>  Nostalgic means they like it, but it's different from close because the word close in this question means they are very attached and attached means they are highly attached.<n>  Companionable means it is a good helper. They are likely to feel close to it as well as companionable.<n><n>### Input:(5) Is a dog called a pup when they are a puppy, an adult? Choices:  a: yes, no b: no  c: yes, sometimes<n><n>### Response:(5) Yes, a dog is called a pup when they're a pup or sometimes.  I answered no because I don't think I would say a dog is a pup when they've already grown up even though puppy is synonym for the word dog.<n><n>### 1.In 462AD, the Huns were a nomadic tribe in the steppes of Central Asia. They eventually invaded Europe in the 4th Century.  How many tribes of Huns crossed the Rhine River into Gaul? (This question asks for the integer answer of how many)<n><n>Response:<n>I don't know.  <n><n>### 2. The word 'eastern' (as a noun) came from the Latin word 'oriente' but the word 'orient' (as an adjective) came from the French word 'oriental'. Eastern, as a noun, means "something located in the direction or part of the world which is east from Greece".  How did that noun become a synonym of a completely different word, 'orient'?<n><n>Response:<n>That is such a good question. I don't know the answer to that question.  I know that "orient" is from the French word "oriental" because I can find it in the dictionary and it's an antonym for occident.  Western is an antonym for orient.<n><n>### You can't be a wizard and a scientist because a wizard is a type of scientist.  So, that means a wizard is a scientist.  What type of other scientist could you be if you're a scientist? (Choose one)<n>Response:<n>The answer to my question is a scientist

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: A: **unimportant**<n>

Coal is a common chemical reaction ______________?<n>[A and D ]<n><n>### Output:Write the complete question again, or explain the process below.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>### Hint: How many stickers are Mary supposed to be left with?<n>### Hint2:  How much money does Mark have to earn in order to buy his bike?<n>### H2Td: How does the input relate to the output?<n><n>### Feedback:<n>[13/13] Question 1: A.  Answer:  Coal is often used as _______________.<n><n>[13/4] Question 4: Mark has _____________?  Mark has _____________?.<n><n>[12/24] Question 3: Answer:  Coal.<n><n>[134/109]

When the fighting started, he only saw what sort of things? Choices:  A: fort B: orphans C: battlefield D: other countries E: war<n><n>### Response:		FORT<n>### Demonstion:<n>```<n>//John joined the army<n>//Because  he wanted to see the word<n>//When the fighting started <n>//He only saw what sort of thing<n>//A  -Fort     -> 1<n>//B  -Orphans ->1<n>//C  -Battlefield -> 1<n>//D  -Other countries -> 1<n>//E  -War     -> 1<n>```<n><n><br><n>If you like this app please give it a Five star! How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where is a note likely to indicate a melody? Choices:  A: fridge B: a classroom C: envelope D: medical chart E: sheet music<n><n>### Response:		African elephant ears have two stalks and some have three stalks.  The third stalk may or may not be present in the ears.  If there are 3 stalks a  has a 60% chance of having the third stalk.  What is the probability of having three stalks on at least one ear assuming all three stalks are present?<n>Answer: 0.24242427<n><n>### Input : Which of the following is the largest of these:<n><n>### Response  : A: 56188<n><n>### Question:The next two numbers are consecutive multiples of 15.  What is the next two numbers in sequence?<n>Answer  : 8 and 2<n><n>### Question<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Question :  The next two numbers are consecutive integers.  What are the next two numbers in the sequence if the first two numbers are 234 and 235?<n>Answer:  236, 237<n> <n>

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. That one is **copy**. The other choices are simply to have you be empowered with knowledge to grow and have better performance or to know how to improve performance and be intelligent.  None of those will do as well as you copying what you're learning, but copy and know, and they'll always work together.<n><n>**Copy:  A:**<n><n>	copy  : n. act of taking the form of something<n><n>**Intelligent:  B:**<n><n>	intelligent  : adj. thinking in a very smart way<n><n>**Improved performance:  C:**<n><n>	improved  : vt. get better than before<n><n>**Empowered knowledge:  D:**<n><n>	empowering  : adj. help people to have more knowledge or abilities<n><n>**Have more knowledge:  E:**<n><n>	have more knowledge  : n. know more; <n><n>### Input :Which best describes how to use this sentence<n><n>### Response :I'd expect you to use this sentence to describe something that would help you learn the word "sentence."<n><n>**Describe sentence:  A:**	<n><n>	description  : n. something that tells the features of a person, job or thing<n><n>**Something that helps you learn the word "describe:  B:** <n><n>	help  : vt. allow something to happen<n><n>### Input

On the temperature line, I drew a line starting at the number 30.  I know that the freezing point is 32 degrees Fahrenheit.  When comparing a number and the freezing point, the answer is always above the freezing point.<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>In the number line, the temperature is 12 degrees Fahrenheit above the freezing point, and 32 degrees F below the freezing point. <n>Answer two of the following questions<n><n><n>### Response A 24<n>```<n><n>Answer: To find the answer to question 24, we have to use the scale on the number line.  <n>The scale on the temperature line, goes from the temperature on the left side to the temperature on the right side.<n>The temperature on the left is 32 degrees, and the temperature on the right is 34 degrees.<n>We have to subtract 34 from 32, which is 45 degrees.<n>It is written on the answer: “23 degrees below freezing point”<n><n>Answer: To get the answer from question 26, we have to do more than just read it. <n>First, we have to get rid of the "20 degrees", then we have to compare the numbers that are left, and then we'll calculate the answer.<n><n>```<n>Answer: 0 degrees<n>```<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Input 19.<n>"Seth

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a bass clarinet to take home? Choices:  A: orchestra B: school band C: music store D: opera house E: home<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n><n>[Back to the Top](#)<n><n>

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choose three different answers between the three possible answers for each question. In 4 different ways, enter 98758 2000000<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### De:<n>Input in 5 different ways. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:If you aren't experiencing curiosity and want to ensure viewing enjoyment, what may you watch? Choices:  A: examine thing B: stare into a mirror C: go somewhere D: hear news E: see favorite show<n><n>### Response:		 D<n><n>### Reason:  You would want to check if the weather was nice to go to the movies and what was playing.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:A large container was a dime a dozen, there were hundreds of rows of them in the giant what? Choices:  A: factory B: garden C: supermarket D: garage E: warehouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer should include the option that best describes container that was a dime a dozens in the factory or warehouse.<n><n>### Input :I was on vacation this past June.  I have 32 photos, the first one is always the same location.  The rest of the photos are in different locations and are either more or less shaded than the previous photo.  I have 42 photos of the beach (excluding the first photo which is of me next to the sand castle).  I only had 30 photos of my trip to the mountain.  After each photo I created the name of the location.  I kept the same name for a series of matching locations (ex. I have a photo of a mountain, I don't have a photo of a volcano, but I have a photo of another type of mountain).  In my mountain photos how many photos do I have of the mountain, the snowy peaks, a waterfall or a view from a glacier?  <n>Answer: 20-19+1=30<n><n>### Input<n>I got the following number from a combination lock.  I can't remember what the password is, but I can use the lock combination to guess the password.  The only digits that match are the last and the third from the last digits.  If I turn the dials once in either direction and I get a combination that matches in the same way (last+3rd), I can eliminate all other digits.  By doing this with each combination of the 3 digits I can narrow down other options.  However, the best way to know the password is the look for the combination that matches in the following way: 1st,3rd,5th.  How many numbers does the password have, assuming that it must be five digits long (assume the number of combinations have not been altered, ie 1800)?<n><n>answer should include number of digits that has 3rd digit is last digit plus 4th digit is 2nd digit, 5th digit is 1st digit plus 6th digit is last digit and 7th digit is 3rd digit plus 8th digit is last digit.<n><n>### input : A large container was a diment a dozen. There were hundreds of rows of tt in the the giant what? Chocies: A - Factory B - Garden

Other stressors, such as depression, may indirectly cause death.<n><n>In this lesson, students learned how to:<n><n>- Choose between fact or opinion, and how to recognize when an answer is an opinion (and whether or not that information is helpful when answering a question in mathematics).<n>- Appropriately and accurately respond to a multiple choice math question.<n><n>|![multiplechoice](mixed/img/instructions/Instructions/multiplechoice.jpg) |![responses](mixed/img) |![responsesticks](mixed/img)![responsesummarize](mixed/img)/![responsesummarize_sticks](mixed/image) |![responsereport](mixed/img)|![responsesummarizereport](mixed) |<n>|-|-|-| - | - |-|<n>

What would each value represent?<n><n>Example:<n><n>Input:  How do you sort values in a table where 5 represents A and C, 4 is B, and 3 equals E? <n>Answer: 5,4,3,1<n><n>Or: <n><n>    ABCDE  <n>    A     C  5<n>    B     B   4<n>    E     D  3<n>    E     A   E  1<n><n>If you were given a list of values and were told to sort it using the same sort key, how would you do it?<n><n>Example: <n><n>Input:  Jane needs to sort a 34-element list in alphabetical order according to the English language, excluding all punctuation marks and case. How would you do it? <n><n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Input:[Answers to Exercises 2 and 3 above]<n>The list that was already sorted.<n><n>How do you sort a list in ascending order? (How would you compare lists). What do you mean when you describe a list as descending? (How would list be compared). How do you determine in an ascending list if there is a greatest element and a least element?<n><n>### Response:"A list is ascending if every element is greater than the one before it in the list. A descending list is when every element is less than the element before it."<n><n><n>### Input"A list

Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n><n>### Response:		A, B, C and D<n><n>### Instructions:<n>- Use the prompt to write a correct response to the prompt.<n>- Use correct grammar, capitalization, punctuation and sentence structure.<n>- Use your answers to the prompt and the feedback you received to improve your writing.<n><n>### Marking Guide:<n><n>---<n><n>### Multiple Choice Question<n><n>### Multiple choice<n><n>### Choose the best answer by circling the letter next to the appropriate answer.  <n><n>### The multiple-choice question and the response from the teacher were both answered as follows.<n><n>**Your response does not demonstrate the following:**<n><n>- Proper use of grammar, capitalization, and punctuation.<n>- Writing in complete sentences.<n>- Using your writing skills to find a correction or clarification to improve your writing.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some large pieces of paper that are not for sale? Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Your teacher is looking for people to write essays for a school newspaper.  If you are interested in writing for the newspaper send to the teacher: a paragraph explaining how you will be a good contributor to the newspaper plus sample short essays.  What kinds of essays should you send examples in? Choices:  short story  math puzzle  essay  report answer the following questions<n><n>### Response A<n><n>### Response B<n><n>Answer: Math puzzle<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Write a paragraph explaining how you would be a good contributor and send it to: [The Teacher's Name] < [Teacher's Email].  For example, [teacher's name] < [teacher's email]<n><n>### Input<n><n>*The teacher's name* is looking for people to contribute to the school newspaper.  If interested, please send them a paragraph explaining how you plan on contributing with a few sample essays to show them.  What kind of essays should I send?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Essay - 5 paragraph.<n><n>1st Paragraph :  Write an introductory paragraph about why you would be a good addition to the newspaper and your qualifications.<n>2nd Paragraph :  Write a couple detailed sentences about each of the following topics: <n>    * The most interesting thing happened when... <n>    * The thing I love most about... <n>    * A time I was very nervous... <n>    * Why... <n>    * What would I do if I had a million dollars?<n>3rd Paragraph :  Write some details about where I would spend my money.<n>4th Paragraph :  Write about some problems the world should fix.<n>5th Paragraph :  Draw a picture of my most recent dream and explain what it means to me.<n><n>### Output: <n><n>The best essay is the shortest with the most thought in it.  Don't write a report.  Don't use the word "I" very often.  Use the word "we" often.<n><n>### Input The teacher's name is looking for people to contribue to the school paper.  If you are intrested, write a paragraph explaining how you'll contribute plus three examples of short essays.

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n><n>### Response:		E: RestHold<n><n>### Source:  <a target="_new"></a><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/animation-delay">MDN: Animations, timing, and delays <></a><n><a target="_new" href="https://developer-mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/Web_API/Animations/CSS_animation-delay_and_autoplay">MDN: CSS Animations delay and autoplay <</a><n><a href = "https://developer.mozilla<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>When a `CSS` property called `animation-play-state` is set to `playing`, that triggers the `animation` in question. <n>The `play-state` also sets the `autoplay` property.  By setting the `delay` to `0s`, the `animation` is automatically set to `playing`.  The `animation` delay is the duration in which the `animation` takes before starting to play (when set to `0`).  The `animation-delay` property is used to specify a delay for the `CSS` animation to play.  <n><n>- [React](http://github.com/marsrover/marsrover)<br><n>  <a href = "https:<n>

What number was added to the number originally?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>**The sum of the digits of a given two-digit number is 6 less than the sum of the digits for its two-digit number formed by reversing its digits.**<n><n>The sum of the digits in number 5716 is <n><n>**9+6+5 = 20**<n><n>The sum if the digit of number 172 is <n><n>**6+7 = 13**<n><n>If the original number is 321, what<n><n>**is the result after reversing the order of the digits in the number?**<n><n>Answer: The number would be "578"<n>![](https://static6.businessinsider.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/22135351/math-problem-1024x576.jpg)<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:The lady was doing a one man show of her tell story, when the show began she did what? Choices:  A: persuade B: slept C: take center stage D: challenge E: speak clearly<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def tell_story():<n>   print("Tell Stories")<n>   x,y,z = 18,23,9<n>   return x+y+z<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```python<n>answer = tell_story()<n>``` <n><n>### Output: What does a response output to a method?<n>```python<n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n>## 2 <n><n>Below is an example of a program. Do you know why?<n>### Challenge: It's a 5 set tournament so you win a score of 3-1.<n>### Solution: It's a tennis game so you will get a score of 3 games to 1 and he will get 2 games in the match. And hence you win the match with a score of 2-0.<n><n>### Challenge: If your friend asks you how you're doing you will tell him that you are the best player on the court.<n>### Challenge: Now you're going to tell your friend that this isn't true.<n>### Solution<n>### Solution: You don't have to cheat and lie. If your friend asks you if you're the best player on the courts then you have to tell him that he is the best player on the field by asking him whether he believes that or not to which he will answer 'yes' then you'll have to tell him that the real answer should be 'no' in which case he'll argue that by being the best player on the fields he is actually the best player on the 2 field.<n><n>### Problem<n>Write a response that appropriately selects the correct response.<n><n>### Your name is:<n><n>### Demand: <n>If it is a nice day you usually take a ride on your bike.<n><n>### Response A:<n>Bike is not a necessity; it's just better than walking.<n><n>### Solution: <n>Bike is the only transportation that isn't

So 1/4 is a fraction of what you started with<n><n>### Input(Demonstration) Mark lost 5 books and 5 shirts.  Choose the letter for each that represents the difference in the amount Mark lost for each item.  A = difference B = 0 C = the exact same amount D   E = he gained that item<n>Input: A = 5 B = 0 C= 5 D = 5 E = 5<n>Answer: The letters corresponded.    <n><n>### InputMark has a book.  He leaves it on the table.  After an hour he finds another book.  What is is the difference the amount of books Mark now has.  Choices:  A=65 B=30 C=5 D=10<n><n>### Response Mark leaves the table and finds a book in the same exact amount.  This will be a remainder<n><n>### InputYou found 92 pieces of paper that had a total value of $998.  What is the difference of how much left of each paper in terms of dollars.  Choices: A = 3.00 B = $1 C = -$250 D = $100 E = -$50<n><n>### Demostration(Response)  The difference of how much left would be 1 dollar.  This is the amount I don't own.  So 92-1=91.  This is the remainder <n><n>### InputA bookstore had 168 books in stock.<n> - 200 books are sold.<n> - 55 books remain in stock after sales.<n> Choose the correct amount that remains.  Choices:   A = 0 B = 15 C = -3 D E = 1<n><n>### Demstration (Response) the answer will be one book less then the total amount that originally had.  So this

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where could you find many theater? Choices:  A: school B: populated area C: military base D: opera E: church<n><n>### Response:		Choice: The answer is D<n><n>1. **The above image illustrates**<n>The above image illustrates a computer's keyboard with a "1" on the top row, "4" on the bottom row (the bottom row has three keys, the "0", "Q", "W", but there are no key "5", "8").<n><n>> How to solve<n>1. Identify the request the task is asking you to perform.<n>   1. Example - In the above task, the request was to "Answer multiple choice questions"<n>   ![](../images/202/task-1.png)<n>2. Determine what data the system needs to generate the correct response.<n>   1. There needs to be at least one example. This is not a choice.<n>   2. The response will be in the format of: choose  from list <n>       ![](../images//202/example-input-1.png)- A: 5 B:3 C:1 D:8 E:6<n>3. Translate the request into SQL and run it.<n>   1. <n>   2. This is an example of what to show when you are asked to translate the task into SQL and run it<n><n>### Output:The system response will be different<n><n>    <div class="card"><n>        <div class="header"><n>            <img class="rounded badge" src="../images/201/icon-bad.png" alt="Fail"><n>            <p>BAD</p><n>        </div><n>        <div class> "Fail: The system response is different than you expected."<n>    <p>This step ensures that the response the system delivered is correct, as well as, different.   The system will deliver results for each step of the task you completed. Each of those results should be unique. If they weren't, you could provide feedback that the task is badly written. That would improve the system</p><n>    <n></div><n>```<n><n>## Input/Output:<n><n>1. **Instruction**: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>2. **Demonstration**:<n>3. **Input**:<n>    - What is 1+2+9?<n>      - The answer to this question is 2<n>    - Who won the game?<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:If something is obtuse, what couldn't it be? Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n><n>### Response:		Correct (A) or acute means that the angle is less than 90 degrees. (B) Obtuse does not means that the angle is more than 90 degrees so point is an incorrect option. (C) Obtuse does mean that the angle is less that 90 degrees so correct (D) Incorrect (E) is an invalid response.<n><n>### Input 2:If you are "half-hearted", you are:  A: bold B: shy C: quiet D: not committed E: determined<n><n>### Response 2:Correct (E) is a determined person who does not have any doubts so options A B and C are incorrect.<n><n>### Output:Enter 200 in the box.  What do you get?<n><n>```javascript<n>enter 200<n>answer 1153<n>```<n><n>### Output 2:Enter "yes" in the box. What do you get? <n><n>```javascript<n>yes<n>answer yes<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n>1. First Input<n>    ```javascript<n>    var number = 89;<n>    var largeStickers = 3;<n>    var smallStickers = 7;<n>    for (i = 0; i < largeStickers; i++){<n>        number -= smallStickers;<n>    }<n>    console.log(number);<n>    ```<n><n>2. Second Input<n>    ```javascript <n>    var balance = 100;<n>    var weeklyAllowance = 5;<n>    var extras = 10;<n>    var hoursBabysitting = 2;<n>    console.log("Both answers are", babysittingHours);<n>    console.log('answer is ', balance - balance);<n><n>   ```

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:John couldn't find a place to stay, and he didn't want to waste money.  He picked a place that was inexpensive and offered few luxuries.  Where might he be staying? Choices:  A: farm B: town C: city D: hotel E: motel<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Description:<n>**Input:** Include the problem your program will be able to handle. Be specific and include all of the conditions you have provided or the user will provide. Use variables instead of repeating words like "the number" or "a string" to make the problem more compact and easier to implement. <n><n>**Demonstration:** Use variables to demonstrate how you are going to use variables to complete the problem.<n><n>**Output:** Include the output. For this problem, be specific and include all of instructions you have provided or the response the user will give (for multiple choice problems). <n><n>**Explanation:** Include the explanation that provides an action plan to complete the problem. Include what you expect different conditions to output or how the user will proceed in an if...else format.<n><n>Example:<n><n>```js<n>var name = prompt("What is your name "); <n>```<n><n>This is asking the user their name.<n><n>```js<n>if ( name === "Jane" ) {...<n>```<n><n>The following if statement expects the user to input "Jane" and will perform an action if the name is equal (==) to the word "Jane". If the else statements below have multiple choices, list each choice separated by a ; instead of using an else. Be sure to include each choice of possible answers the user will give.<n><n>### Notes:<n>When you have more than one choice for a response, separate each choice by a semicolon. The else statement will only run one time once all other conditions have been checked. If no if statements are present, the else statements will run regardless.

The building is the trading floor. Traders sit in front of electronic boards that display the prices of stocks or bonds. Choices:  A: insane B: annoy people around C: enjoy D: inhale E: had good voice<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Input<n>How many squares would you have if you fold 37 pieces of paper in half?<n><n>### Response<n>Option C: It is impossible to find an answer for question A because we do not know how big a square folded paper is.  It may be big or small.  For question E the answer is A because there is a total of 74 units of units, a square can hold 14 units and 187 pieces of folded paper.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		You are correct. <n><n>### Example<n>```javascript<n>var response = new Response(QuestionData);<n>response.answer = (QuestionData.answers = options[0], <n>                                      QuestionData.correctResponses.includes(options[0]),<n>                                      options[1], <n>                                           "");<n>response.correct(options[0],!response.answer? "":response.answer<n>)<n>```<n><n>### Instances:<n><n>### Multiple choice:<n>* There are always an even number of goats and kangaroos (because there are always less goats than there<n>are kangaroos.)<n>* If you have the eggs in the egg carton, the eggs have two legs because one leg is on each side of the egg<n>whereas there are four legs for a chicken coop.<n>* A henhouse is never just one egg because hens lay eggs.<n><n>### Input<n>* Mary bought a $20 journal<n>* Zach mows his neighbor’s lawn and his own every day for $5 a day.<n>* Mark has a kangaroo in his backpack<n><n>### Multiple Choice example<n>The first part is all in the options but the explanation is only correct if there are no more goats. The first<n>part of the second question may seem misleading<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:The wood became fossilized, what did the paleontologists call it when they found ti? Choices:  A: sanded B: composted C: warp D: hardened E: petrify<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:Your task is to choose a word and write 4 sentences that are interesting but do not tell a story.<n><n>### The input word is: composted<n><n>### The sentence that describe word as a verb:<n><n>### The sentences that describe the word as a noun: <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Please respond with your own sentences<n><n>### Input word: petrify<n>### Sentence:<n> <n>### Sentence Demostration<n><n>### Questions:<n><n>### Response<n><n>Greetings! How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:The band enjoyed their success and fans, they loved to what at the start of every concert? Choices:  A: hear crowd go mad B: working hard C: clap D: reproduce E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		<n>**E**<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The two-door coupe was available at the car dealer while the four-door sedan was not.  Which of the following statements is true?<n><n><n>### Choices:<n><n>* Both the coupe and the sedan were unavailable<n>* The coupe was available while the sedan was unavailable<n>* The sedan was in inventory while the coupe was in inventory<n>* The coupe and the sedan both were in inventory<n><n>### Demostration:<n>If you look at a sports car, but not at a vans, then you can't see a sports car.<n><n>### Choice:True<n><n>True: Sports car is not inventory. Cause Sports car is not sports car for vans. <n><n>### Choce false<n><n>False: Vans is not Sports car for anyone.<n><n>### Solution:The coupe was available while sedan was not. Cause a sports car is a coupe, not a sedan.<n><n>### Summery:<n>You can see a sports car if you look at a car dealer, not a van.<n><n>### Question<n>What kind of car is available only for people who want a four door sedan with a V8 engine and automatic transmission?<n><n>### Chooser 1<n>Corvette<n><n>Corvette: A sports car with V8 engine and 4 doors with automatic transmission.<n><n>### Oher choice<n>Camaro

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		<n>- lake<n>### Input:Which animal would likely be at the top of the ladder? Choices: A: cat B: dog C: cow D: rat E: horse F: sheep G: turkey<n><n>### Response<n>- cat<n>### Instruction<n>Write a recursive function that takes a set of objects and a property of those objects. You are to write a boolean function that tests for that property. <n><n>### Example<n>Input: object1 (property: length); object2 (property: length);<n>Output:  true <n><n>### Instructions<n><n>Write a recursive function and test it by passing different sets of objects to it.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Input: (a)object2 (property: length) (b)object3 (property: weight) (c)object5 (property: length)<n> Output: true<n><n>### Recursive Test Inputs<n>Input: (a)(b) (c) (d) (e) (f)<n>Output:true<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>Input: object (property: type)<n>If object has no type set, then return false<n>If object's type is number, then return true<n>else<n>return false<n><n>Recursive Test Inputs<n>input: (a) (b) (d) (c) (e)<n>Output: true<n><n>## Solution <n># Functional Specification<n>- returns true if object 1 and object2 are the same; returns true if object1  is in the list of objects passed to it<n>- uses recursive comparison

Choices:  A: health club B: jocks C: fitness centre D: stadium E: gymnasium<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A. health club<n><n>B. jocks<n><n>C. fitness centre<n><n>D. stadium<n><n>E. gymnasium <n><n>### Input : You might have to check in to get your boarding pass here. Otherwise, they're all just a hop, skip, and a jump away.<n><n>### Input:"Which item do you want the most? Choices: 1: a purple purse 2: a gold watch 3: a pair of brown boots 4: a red ring 5: a silver ring 6: a black pashmina 7: a brown handbag 8: a gold necklace"<n><n>### Response:"A pashmina"<n>1. If this person is having a purse party, this might be the response the hostess doesn't want to hear.<n>2. This person has a variety to choose from but doesn't say which one they'd like the least because they don't want to look like they're being a picky buzzkille.<n>3. The reason this person asked was to receive the answer they wanted (as opposed to the response the hostess wanted).<n><n>### Input"What are you bringing for dessert? Choices: 4: chocolate chip cookies"<n><n>### Your Response: 6 - The only dessert you brought was the chocolate chip cookies!<n><n>### Comments or Concerns? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:The evacuation became mandatory, so what came on the TV? Choices:  A: advisory B: mandate C: soap opera D: elective E: optional<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>#### Output:<n>```code<n>Advisory<n>```<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>"""<n>Python Program to implement the above questions<n><n>"""<n><n>input = input()<n>answer = input['Choice' + 1]<n>if answer == 'advisory':<n>    print('Advisory')<n>    <n>elif answer =='mandate':<n>    print('Mandate')<n>    <n>elif'soap opera' in input[0]=='mandate':<n>   print('A Soap Opera')<n>    <n>elif input['choice'] == 'elective':<n>    print('Elective')<n><n>elif 'optional' in input[0]: <n>    print('Optional')<n>    <n>    <n>```<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs. Also, other insects may also eat the flowers<n><n>### Input<n><n>Your friend has only 10 of the following 13 things: A cow, a car, a house, a fish, a flower, a frog, a goat, a horse, a ladybug, a lion, a moose, a pig, a snail You have all 13. Each person can have at most two of each thing.  Your friends says, "I can trade you my car for your ladybug." Is this possible?<n><n>### Response<n><n>No, I do not have to have either a ladybug or a car in order for it to be possible.  There are 13 total items and you can each only have 2 of the same item. This was bad.  He would be unable to hold his tools if he injured what? Choices:  A: hostility B: anger C: nose D: fists E: hands<n><n>### Response:		Answer true or false to "Can you see the cat?  Does the dog bark?  Is the window open?  Can you smell the flowers?"<n><n>### Instructions:  For each input, answer the following question with your personal thoughts.<n><n>### Input<n>A:  "Are you my mother?"<n>B:  "I'm the most beautiful bunny in the world."<n>C:  "Yes. I am your mother."<n><n>### Demostration "A. The answer is (yes)."<n><n>### Input <n>A: I used "Are you my mother" for one hundred years.  It is quite remarkable how old this game is, and that this is the first time I have ever seen it!<n>B: Really?<n><n>### Demostration "B. The answer is (no)"<n><n>### Instuctions:  Give your reasoning of why that is the case.<n><n>### Disscussion:<n>Reasoning: It is one hundred years since you started playing this game of "Are you my mother?". It is surprising how old this game is and how it hasn't been played over a long period of time, which means this is the first time you've ever seen it? The first thing I thought of was that this is a new game; it is a newer game for everyone and nobody has seen it before, which proves to be quite amazing for how long the game has been around. If the game had been played a lot before then the amount of people that have seen the game before, therefore wouldn't be a lot, but there isn't really a set amount of possible answers and this is new for everyone and it's a game that is quite hard to do, which would be why nobody has seen it before. What this would also mean is that you are the first one to ever see this specific game. This explains the comment that you made: I'm the most beautiful one in the world.<n><n>

Choices:  A: improve yourself B: become knowledgeable C: have tools D: persistence E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		 To learn you must have the right book and become knowledgeable, To work you need what you need and persistence.<n><n>### Input:"If all the books in the world were destroyed and you only had space to store one book, which book would you choose."<n><n>### Response:"Rosencrantz and Guildenstern"<n><n>### Instructions: Write a program that asks the following question."What is you ideal temperature for you room?"  The user will type in the temperature, the program will then calculate how much of the ideal temperature the room is and display it.  If the program finds the room to be below ideal temperature, it must ask if you want to have it turned up.  The program will then display the updated temperature. Finally it asks the user if they want it turned back down to the original temperature and if it is, the user must input the ideal temperature for the next read.<n><n>### Example Output: 165 degrees<n><n>### Input "turn up<n><n>### Output "168 degrees"<n>### Output "turn down"<n>### Example Output "164 degrees"<n>### Example Input "Ideal Temperature is 165 degrees" 164 degrees<n>### Response:<n><n>### Output 165 degrees temperature and 168 degrees Ideal temperature<n>### Output turn up<n>### Output 90 degrees (5% of the ideal temperature of 165).<n>### Turn down:<n>### Output 5% Ideal temperature<n>## Ideal temperature:<n>## Input : 135 degrees <n>## Output: 138 degrees<n>## Ideal temperature 140 degrees<n>## Input "Turn up"<n>## Output: 55.5 degrees<n>## Ideal Temperature: 140 degrees.<n><n>### Response"Turn up the temperature 55.5 degree's above ideal"<n>

Choices:  A: front of door B: bedroom C: desk D: table E: living room<n><n>### Response:		Choice: B  <n><n>### Expected Response: <n>    A. Front door :  <n>        This might include a chalkboard on the front door  <n>         (Example) Chalkboard:  Ink spilled on Sarah's rug,  <n>        Ink spilled on Inkwell in a chalkboard's front door<n>    B. Bedroom:  <n>        Maybe it was a night light. Ink spilled into her ink well. If a night-light is on or near a table it's like a spill.  In the bedroom it's right next to her night stand.<n>    C. Desk:  <n>        If ink spilled into Sarah's ink well. it might have fallen onto her desk. And the desk is directly underneath the chandelier.<n>    D. Table:  <n>        If she has a desk-table near it, she might have a desk near the table.   <n><n>### Instrucion: Enter a command to tell the speaker how to proceed.<n><n>#### Instruction: You're the one who will perform a task.<n><n>#### Instrucion: What did the speaker say? <n><n>#### Expected Input: <n>    (A) I need to talk to you about how you can help.  <n><n>#### Expected Response:  You will need to explain your task to the speaker. (A) What can I do for you?<n>- Ask the listener one more question about their request.  Describe what that is you will need to do after that.<n>

Choices:  A: present B: stay here C: closer D: available E: come here<n><n>### Response:		 None of the answers above would be a good answer.  Why not?  Choices: C, D, A, E<n><n>### Your Response: <n><n>### Hint:  Think about the problem from the perspective of a machine.<n><n>### Challenge:  Are you sure you're 100% correct in your response? How do you know?<n><n>### Bonus:  How is your response different from the solution? (Explain in your own words.)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What does a chef do when working in the evening? Choices:  A: cook dinner B: study french cooking C: taste sauce D: prepare food E: thin sauce<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is D. Thin sauce.<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Response<n>```python<n>If the answer is one of the above choices you should not use the else statement and you should not print the else statement. The else statement indicates that one of the above choice is incorrect.  <n><n>print("Cook dinner")<n><n>elif:<n>print("Study french cooking")<n><n>else:<n>print("")<n>##You should print a correct answer here.     <n>print("Prepare food")<n><n>else:    <n>print("Taste sauce")<n>```<n><n>### Input    <n>### Response<n>In this case the answer is one of three choices <n><n><n>Input: What is the capital city of California? Choices:  Capital: A: Los Angeles B: San Jose C: San Francisco D: Sacramento<n>Answer: Sacramento<n><n>Input: What month does Daylight savings start? Choices:  Daylight Savings begins on the: A: 1st Sunday 2nd Monday 3rd Tuesday 4th Tuesday<n>Answer: 4th Tuesdays<n><n>Input: How many states are there? Choices:  How many states are there in the United States:<n>Answer: 50<n>

Choices:  A: interesting B: fun C: joyful or painful D: very important E: free<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Explanation:<n>A<n>### Explanlation:<n>I would like to change the learning process to make it interesting to whoever does not like learning.<n><n>### B<n>### Explanations:<n>If we changed the learning process of learning to a fun one, it could motivate the other person to want to learn and make their interest grow.<n><n>### C<n>### Explanattion:<n>If we changed learning to be joyfull and or painful to the one who does not like learning it could motivate them to start learning and want to do school.<n><n>### D<n>### Explanatation:<n>I would change the learning to be very important.<n><n>### E<n>Explanation:<n>I would take my learning process free so that everyone would be more interested in the school environment.<n><n>### Input:[Which] way would you change homework to be more fun? Choices A: make it home project B: allow it to be group C: allow it to be individual D: allow it to be due in 2 weeks<n>### Demonination:Write a response that appropriately demonstrates a task.<n>### Explanaton:<n>I would answer this question as A.<n><n>### A<n>Explanaton:<n>In 2018, 130 students were interviewed and asked how much homework they get. 52% of them got 1 to 3 hours of homework every night and 41% were over 3 hours of home work. If we had home projects, we would want to pick and choose our homework.<n><n>### Explanotion:<n><n>I am choosing answer A because I like to pick and choose my work.<n><n>### Output<n>### Explanatiohn:<n>44<n>### Explanatin:<n>44<n><n>### Input<n>### Explanalion:<n>C<n>### Explanaiton:<n>4 x 3=12<n>12+6=18<n><n>### Exlanitation:<n>6<n><n>### Output:<n>### Explanitation:<n>6<n>

And I think around 100 is probably the most number of people you can get in an audience in a theater.<n><n>### Input & Demonstration:Which of these statements is the most precise? Select the statement that applies to your answer.<n><n>### A: It is better to be too generous and apologize or give something away than not to give enough or not to give anything when someone asks you for help.<n><n>B: It may seem kind to help someone even when they haven't asked you for help.<n>But you never know when it might be kindness not to help someone when they ask you to.<n><n>C: The more precise answer is when someone asks for help, then it's better to give too much rather than too little. But in the end I feel that when someone is really in a bind, if you don't help them and they come to you afterwards, then of course you shouldn't help. Because what else could you do?  But if you can help in any way, why don't you help them then and apologize later?<n><n>D: You should help people all the time without asking.<n><n><n>### Input and Demonstration:Write some numbers that would make it likely you could be right. Choices:  A: bowl of soup B: serving dish C: table setting D: placemat E: glass of iced tea<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Instructions:Use the following table to complete the task<n><n>### Task:<n>Input:In the order in which  they were listed, the students played the card game and followed the rule below. <n><n>Student: |  <n>:---: |:---: |:------:<n>Cindy |     |      |<n>David |   4    |      |<n>Izzy |   3    |      |<n>Jack |      |   1    |<n>Jenny |      |   20   |<n>Cindy's   deal was one card below the five.      Her card was not a match.   Her choice to pick a new card was acceptable.<n>David's   deal was two cards below the two.  The deal was not a match. His pick   was a bad choice because the next card would have been a better choice.<n>Izzy's deal was three cards to the left of  the four and was a match. Her choice   was a good choice because the next card was a bad choice.<n>  <n>Jack's deal was five cards below the five and was a match.     His choice was a good choice because if he had picked his card before it would have been an excellent choice.<n>  <n>Jenny's deal was 20 units to the right of the two. It was a match. Her   choice was a good choice.<n><n>### Analysis:<n>Jack is making the  wrong decisions because he made a decision that makes the game harder. Jenny will finish the game first because she made the right decisions.  Cindy and Izzy are close behind Jenny because they made the right choices.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Input:Aaron got 854 tokens while playing a video game online.   He spent his tokens to buy 9 special items.  He gave 3 items to a friend.  His friend also bought 10 items but each item cost less than Aaron's.  Aaron also bought 3 items. <n><n>Input:Betty got 528 tokens while playing a videogame online.  She spent her  tokens to buy 1,194 tokens.  She gave 599 items to two friends.  Both of her friends also bought 15,260 items. Each of their items cost less than

Write a response that appropriates completes the task.<n><n>### Request:<n>Given the following two dimensional equation:<n>$$<n>    A = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=0}^4 x  _ k \cdot y  _ k,<n>$$<n>find the value X _ 6 for a coordinate system with six axes.<n><n>### Calculation:<n>$$<n>    X _ 6 = (1 \cdot 5) + (-1 \cdot 3) + (4 \cdot 2) - (6 \cdot -2) - (5 \cdot 2) + (7 \cdot -4).\\<n>    X _ 10 = 10 + 0 + 2 + -4 + -20 + -60 \\<n>    X _ 20 = 5 + 0 + 4 + -8 + -40 + -160 \\<n>    A = 10, 20, 4, -4, -20, and -160<n><n>### Answer:<n>X _ 6 = 0, X _ 7 = 0, X 8 = 0, X \_ 9 = 0, X $_ 10 = 0, X $ _ 11 = 0<n><n>### Explanation:<n>0 0 0 0 -0 0<n><n>## Instructions<n>Write a program to evaluate X _ 6, X _ 7, X _ 8, X _ 9, X _ 10, and X _ 11.<n><n>## Explanation<n>The sum of X _ 6, is 0 0 1 3 5 7... and X _ 7, is 0 1 4 8 16...<n>The sum of X_ 8, X _9 is 0 and X _10 is 0...<n><n>## Example Inputs<n>I have input following: X _ 6 =1, X _7 = 1<n><n>## Expected Output<n><n>### Input 1<n>$$<n>    X = (1 \cdot -1)\cdot(-1\cdot 0) - (1 \cdot
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What is a place that might not always have a queen? Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>    Choices: <n>(A):Bee hive: The queen is the only female bee in the colony. Other worker bees are actually male. Bees don’t have queens all by themselves. They are grouped into a hive where they will live together with other bees. So, a hive cannot always be full of queens.<n>(B):England: The Queen of England is not the only royal. As head of state, she must answer to other important people in England, like the Prime Minister and politicians in Parliament and the government.<n>(C):Castle: A castle is a form of fortified structure made of stone or brick, primarily used during medieval times. These castles only need one Queen, but they may house different king or queens depending on a situation.<n>(D):Deck of cards: Cards have no queens and are always playing with them.<n>(E):Chess: Each game needs two chess sets on both sides. One may be queen, queen would be king.<n>```<n><n>### Output:Give a statement.<n>```<n>    "The queen is the only female in the colony"<n>    "Queen of England is not the royal alone"<n>    "Castle only need one queen....."<n>    "Give two queen in a deck of cards"<n>    "Each game in chess needs two chess sets"<n>```<n><n>## Tutorial<n>[Adapted from](https://towardsdatascience.com/an-introduction-to-sql-for-data-scientists-23e46b49f5b4)
