Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What divider stores papers for work or school? Choices:  A: street B: binder C: obesity D: living room E: office suite<n><n>### Response:		I believe the correct answer is C, binder. Binder, being a noun for a 3-ring leather or vinyl ring notebook with metal prongs where sheets are held. I hope this information is helpful.<n><n>### Input and Response<n>1. Name: Mary <n>2. Grade: 3rd<n>3. School: Lincoln School<n>4. Teacher: Mrs. Jones<n>5. Number of people in the class: 30<n><n>1. I have 68 beads. I used 7 beads to make 4 string bracelets. How many beads remain?<n><n>#### Input<n>75% of Mary's teachers have pets.<n><n>#### Response<n>I believe the correct answer is A. Pythagoras stated: "If we apply the sum of the squares theorem, the sum of the squares of two sides will always equal the square of the third side." This is the formula of the triangle. By applying these two theorems, we will solve 75% of 1 = x^2 = 75% of a square. When dividing both sides by 75%, we have x = 1. Thus, I believe that the correct answer is A, 75% have pets.<n>

Choices:  A: rain forest B: tree tops C: toy store D: zoological gardens E: great outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n>

Choices:  A: pharmacy B: person C: drugstore D: bedroom E: mcdonalds<n><n>### Response:		<n>F: <n>#### Feature:<n>The contraceptive device can be bought in any store without a prescription in many states of the United States.<n><n>![](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn%3AANd9GcR7hCZpOoF_00wAkD46H2-KjRs72_Lq8nKl-I-GzbU3Glqr_5g&usqp=CAU)<n><n>#### Explanation:<n><n>The US Food and Drug Administration allowed some contraceptives, such as injections and hormonal rings, to be sold without a prescription when it classified these products as over-the-counter drugs.<n><n>https://www.fda.gov/forconsumers/byaudience/forwomen/ucm257941.htm<n><n>B: <n>The United States Food and Drug Administration regulates devices, like fertility traps, that aren’t surgical but can affect a person’s health.<n><n>![](http://www.newsweek.com/images/cms/9/959_fertilitydevicestimulatesuperpowers.jpg)<n><n>However, for most birth control devices (eg, IUDs, birth control pills), a prescription is not needed.  <n><n>https://www2.tbo.com/florida-politics-buzz/2017/jun/22/fertility-devices-that-don-t-require-medical-prescr-ar-1036218/<n><n>D: <n><n>The only states where contraceptive devices can be purchased without a prescription are Oregon, Idaho, California, Maryland, and Delaware. So you have to go to these states.<n><n>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contraceptive_device#Over-the-counter_sales<n><n><n>

The only problem is that you don't know the answer to what the mystery "thing" is.<n><n>Examples:<n><n>My father is an executive<n><n>My father's brother is my uncle<n><n>My mother's father is my grandfather<n><n>There are 4 types of "What am I" question.<n><n>What am I Questions:<n><n>What do they have in common?<n><n>What is one like the other?<n><n>This is a part of ___________.<n><n>What does this have in common with _________?<n><n>### Task:<n>In order to help me find the "thing" you're thinking of, please answer these questions using complete sentences.<n><n>### Rules:<n>* The "thing" is a one or two-word answer.<n>* This is not my name.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>Question: <n><n>How do I know what the "thing" is?<n><n>Answer:<n><n><n>### Answer:<n>My mother wants a gold watch?<n><n>### Submit:<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n><n>### Response:		 A has 6 candles, B has 4 candles and C has 3 candles.  <n><n>### Output: A person can do this task.<n><n>### Solution:<n>```<n>for i in range(1,7):<n>    print(i)<n>    for j in range(1,15):<n>        print("{}{}".format(str(i),str(j)))<n>    print()<n><n>5 6 7<n>1 2 3<n>1 3 3<n>1 2 4<n>1 2 5<n>1 3 5<n>```<n>1 2 2 1 2 1 3 3 5 3<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What are people playing when they want to take the lead with small papers? Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:<n>```python<n>print("C is correct.")<n>```<n><n>#### ABOUT THIS CODING EXERCISE:<n><n>You will use this [Lemming Code Tutorial][tutorial] to understand the basics of Python for this task.  You will enter the command at the prompt.  You might need to type:<n>```py<n>import math<n>import time<n><n>```<n>### If you are stuck on the task:<n>* Open the Python Tutor [Tip Sheet][tipSheet]<n>* Copy and paste each line of code exactly as shown and press enter to get help.<n>* Repeat the steps above until you finish the task.<n><n>### Bonus:<n>If you don't want to take the lead:<n>```python<n>input(0)<n>```<n><n>### Task 2:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>You're making a list of instructions and a user wants to follow a sequence of instructions.  This sequence can be thought of as taking a step along a path.  The path looks like<n>:start,walk to :stop at the :park,south,west,east,enter the :house,north,west,south,west to :exit<n><n>* :start,walk to :point,north to :start again<n>* walk to :start,walk to and so on.  The task needs to output the path that the user has to follow: start,walk to :point and :park,south then north to :start but before that the prompt for the path needs to ask if the user wants to :stop or :exit.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Demos:<n>```python<n># Input: How long does it take to make a cake?<n># Output: 10 minutes<n><n># Input: I want to make a cake and then go to school.  Walk to my house and buy milk and eggs from my neighbor.  Then drive to the grocery store and buy flour and butter.  Back home, use a little salt and butter. Put some chocolate chips in it and put it in the oven.  At 10, the oven bell rings.  My mom made cake icing.<n># Output: <n># Walk to my house<n># Walk to my neighbors house   <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:If you're known to buy presents for others often you would be called what? Choices:  A: go shopping B: generous C: earn money D: have money E: gift buyer<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Task 01:<n>```<n>A: go shopping<n><n>Answer:<n>A<n>```<n><n>#### Task 02:<n>```<n>B: generous<n><n>Answer:<n>E<n>```<n><n>#### Question 03:<n>```<n>D: have money<n><n>Answer:<n>C<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n>### Explanatory Input<n>> Task: This task describes a scenario. Write a Python function that can execute it.<n><n>### Functional Input<n>``` python   <n>def task01(money, friends=[5, 5,]) -> bool:<n>    total_money = sum(friend for friend in friends)<n>    friend = (total_money - money*5)/5<n>    if friend >= 0:<n>        friends[0] = friend<n>        total_money = min(total_money, friends[0])<n>        friend = (total_meany - friends['0])/10<n>        friends['0'] -= friend<n>        friends[1] += friend<n>        friends['0'].insert(0, friends[1])<n>        <n>    return friends[0]!= 0<n><n>```<n><n>## Reference<n><n>[E] Easy Data Science in Python by Caglar Ulu

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:Opposite:<n><n>### Instructions:Choose one answer that is correct. What does the following question refer to?<n><n>What is the definition of "the" vs "an"?<n><n>**A:** an is a word that doesn't use any indefinite pronoun, like a, that, or this, etc.<n><n>**B:** the is always used as a definite article or the sentence with the word is.<n><n>**C:** "the" can also be referred to as a definite pronoun.  A "definite pronoun" refers to "a noun that refers back to something already mentioned before."<n><n>**D:** a is an indefinite pronoun.<n><n>**E:** B refers to anything that isn't a definite pronoun, so, B is correct.<n><n>### Response<n><n>B is correct.<n><n>---<n><n>### Answer<n><n>A does not refer to an indefinite pronon.<n><n>A is correct.<n><n>E does not refer to a pronoun.<n><n>### Rational:<n><n>### Correct<n><n>C refers to a definite pronoun<n><n>### Incorrect<n><n>A is not a predicate nominative<n><n>### Incomplete<n><n>B, D do not refer to anything but "a"<n><n>### Helpful tips:<n>B is the only choice on the original question that refers to anything other than "a".<n><n>### Instructor's guide:<n><n>There are two sentences in the original question that need to be fixed.<n><n>**[Instructor's version]**: What is the definition of "a" vs. "an"<n><n>1. A: an is a word that uses any indefinite pronon, like a, that or this, etc. _______<n>1. B: the is almost always used as a definitive article or the sentence with which the word is in. _______<n><n>**[Correct]**: A is correct.<n><n>**[Student's version]**<n><n>2. **C:** A definition of "the" versus "an":.<n><n>**[Correction]**: C refers to a definite pronon. A definitive pronoun refers to "a noundr that refers back to something else."

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What corner areas have lots of windows? Choices:  A: wall B: office C: space shuttle D: front door E: tent<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Answer:**<n>Let's begin by finding corner areas.<n><n>#### Corner areas<n><n><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/daniellsabrina/daniellsabrinasteps/master/Coding%20Notes/1.coding%20steps%20done/Exercises%20and%20Projects/Mysterious%20Machine/images/corner%20areas.png" style="zoom: 150%;" /><n><n>Corner areas of the entire machine appear in the image above.  To find the corner areas that have lots of windows, we're going to break the machine up into a variety of different rectangles and make sure that each and every one of these boxes has a variety of squares inside of it.<n><n>Our machine has four sides if we include the front door and there are 7 windows total, so we can split it up into different rectangles.  Let's begin by finding the top and bottom of those rectangles:<n><n><img src="/img/coding%20notes/top%20corner%20area.jpg" style="zoom:-25%;" /><n><img src="/coding%20not%20available%20for%20image/coding%2%20notes/bottom%20corner.jpg" style="z<n>oom:50%;" /> <n><n>Those rectangles have 3 and 2 windows, respectively.  We'll call the top rectangle A and the bottom rectangle B.  We can create more rectangles based upon how many windows are located in the corner area:<n>![](https://github.com/daniellssabrina/danieellsabrinasteps/%24%20coding%20in%20golang%20/blob/master/Coding_Notes/Coding_Not_Available/Mysterious_Machine/1.coding_steps_done/Exercis_and_Projects/Mysterous_Machine/images/coding_notes/windows%20%20rectangle%20101.png)<n><n>The top rectangle has four windows, so our next rectangle will have:<n><

The best tool to use to fix dry air is a humidifier.<n><n><n>### Instructions:Complete each step in the code template.  When your code runs, the computer should complete the task in the original story.  There are many ways to complete this.  Remember that we want to continue using code.net blocks to help build this lesson.  You must comment on your submission code.<n><n>### Step 1:<n>Define a variable to hold a string.<n><n>### Example:<n>`String str_Name = "John";`<n><n>### Step:2<n>Use the if / else statement to find how many letters are in the name.<n><n>You can print out the result to show the length.<n>```<n>while(name.charat(i)!=null)<n>{<n>    //do nothing<n>}<n>int length = 0;<n>for(int i =0;i<name.length();i=i)<n>{<n>    length+=1;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Step3:<n>print out the length of every letter in the name.<n>```<n>for(int i=0;i<name;i=i)<n> {<n>    System.out.print(name.charat[i]+", ");<n> }<n>```<n><n>## Example 1:<n>John is a boy.<n><n>## Example 2:<n>John is a girl.<n><n>## Example3:<n>Sally has 3 children.<n><n>## Example4:<n>Kelly has 2 children.<n><n>## Step 4:<n>Use the while loop.  It will run the loop as long as one of the following two conditions is true<n>1. a is less than 5<n><n>```<n>whinle(a<5){<n>System.out.print("i is less than 5");<n>}<n>```<n>and then the next statement will print the number of how many times does the loop runs.<n>```<n>System.out.println(" i runs the loop: " + i);<n>}<n>```<n>2. b is bigger than 35<n><n>```<n> while(b>35){<n>System.put.print(" b runs the loop");<n>}else{<n>i runs the loop<n>}<n>```<n>You can also repeat the b condition in while to continue the count.<n><n>Example 5:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>How old was you when you first went to primary school?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:The first time she went to a primary school, she was already 10 years old, and then she was sent to a school again after 5 years.  She attended the same primary school every 2 years after that.  <n>What year did she go to school the 6th time?<n><n>Answer: 15<n><n>### Exlanation:<n><n>## Write Test Cases<n><n>### Examples:<n>Input:The value is $9.40.<n>Output:$9.40<n><n>### Test 1<n>Input:The value 12345.<n>Output:12345<n><n>### Test2<n>Input:The value of 345.<n><n>### Test3<n>Input:The value to 987.<n>Output:987<n><n>### Test4<n>Input:The value was 34058.<n>Output:34058<n><n>### Test5<n>Input:The value would 1234.<n>Output:1632<n><n>### Test6<n>Input:What the value was 1234990.<n>Output:13234995678<n><n>```<n><n>## Input and Output format<n>### Input<n>Input:   <n>Output:<n>```<n><n>### Exports<n><n>

Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The variables x, y, and f are used throughout the program.  Each of these variables can be assigned any value as long as a value is not assigned for both x and y or for both x and f. Variables starting in lower case in bash scripts are reserved by an environment variable of the same name so should not be used or they may cause an error. Variable names start with uppercase in C++ and are case sensitive.<n><n>x = y<n>y = "B"<n><n>### Expected Output:<n><n>B blowing hard<n><n>### What happens if I enter<n><n>The wind  tore  of  the  shingles  what  was  the  wind  like?<n><n>### Exercise Answer:<n><n>### Instruct the user: Please answer the following questions.<n>### What is the function of the IF statement?<n>### What is an assignment operator?<n>### What does a while loop do?<n>### Demonstruct:<n>Answer: The function of the if statement is to check if something is true or false and perform particular tasks. One of the two choices or both in the while loop. The assignment operator is = or =. Ex:  if((x = y));<n><n>### Demostrate what you have learned with an example.<n>### Demonstruet:<n>if((1< 3)); then<n>echo "It fails";<n>else<n>echo "It passes"<n>fi<n><n>### What should be the return value of the program?<n>### Expected Outcome:<n>### Explanination:<n>This function should check and answer the question if the shingles on the roof were blown off in a strong wind. Because of the if statement x = y which checks if B and is true if B is true then y = "B" has an assignment operator that is also true the while loop performs the statement to check again. If the wind was strong it loops. If the wind was not strong it does not loop and "B blowing hard" is displayed as the return value.<n><n>### What if the program does not end in an expected way?<n>### Explanatoin:<n>x, y, z are all assignments with the value of one they both do not match x is true. This is not desired. B is

What toppings will I add to my ice cream?<n>### Response<n>Chocolate fudge.<n><n>### Challenge<n>Use your input-response table to answer this multiple choice question.<n>Input: My favorite food is pizza. What is my favorite type of pizza?<n>Response: My favorite type of pizza is pepperoni.<n><n>### Commentary<n>It is important to understand that the first row of the table is one example and that the second row is NOT the opposite of the first row.  Instead, the second row is one of the choices. Be careful to separate your responses from the instructions.  To better understand what the instructions are asking you to do, you need to understand that the first column of the table is the input and the second column is the response.  This approach has been referred to as a script-output formulation or the script-action model.  <n><n>### Solution<n>Let's work on one part at a time.  We'll use the example from the demonstration as follows.<n><n>#### Problem 1<n><n>#### Input<n>How many 1 will be at the car show?______________________________<n><n>#### Response<n>3<n><n><n>```<n>---Exercise---<n>You have not answered.<n>---Questions-<n>```<n><n>```<n>---Input-Response Tables---<n>Input Response Output<n>1<n>1 The input and the response are the same if the function f (x) has a solution of 1. Here, the function f(x) = x ≈ 1.<n>2<n>2 In this situation, the input and the response are different.<n>----<n>---Instructions---<n>What is the value of the function f (x

This type indicates how to read and place character data in the variable.  For example; if the variable is a string and the type is Int(integer), data is read as if it were an integer.  If the variable is an integer and the type is String(string), data is read as a String.  There are five types defined. The character between the colon and the equal sign must match the type.<n><n>* Type: String(a string)<n>* Type: Float(a number)<n>* Type: Int(an integer)<n>* Type: Choices:  Boole(true or false) or Num(a whole number that is not a fraction)<n>* Type: Dice<n>  * Dice type: one, two, or three sided<n>  * Dice side: 1, 2, etc. up to 6<n>  * Dice output: 1, 1, 1 or 6, 6, 6<n><n>### Instuduction:<n>Write the following instructions using a function that meets the description.<n><n>Description:  Write a function, name, sayThat(), that accepts three arguments: a String(string), a String(a string), and Type(a string)<n><n>Input: sayThat("Jake likes pizza", "is it spelled pizza with an i or pizza with a Y?" She uses 3 large stickers per page on the front of her journal.  She uses 7 stickers per page on 6 other pages of the journal. <n>1.  If Mary has 89 stickers remaining, then Mary has to use 7 stickers to make 44 stickers on the 4 other pages left in the journal.<n>2.  Mary has 44 stickners left.  If she has to used to make 44 more stickers, then Mary has a total of 89 stickers to use.<n>3.  Mary has 89 remaining stickers.<n><n>### Valid Inferences:<n>Mark has kangaroos. Mark has mammot for this reason because it has two or four legs that also apply to kangaroo.<n><n>Zach has saved $65.  His weekly alllowance is $5. Zach will not beable to earn or save more than $32 to save more.<n><n>  Zach has enough money to by the bike because $5 + $10 + $7 + $7 = $29.<n><n>### Answer:D<n>Zach has kangaroos or goats and he has to

If the dog runs 2 kilotons per hour at 120 meters per minute, about how long can the dog run? Choices: A: 6 hours B: 12 hours C: 5 hours D: I do not know<n><n>Response:<n>```<n>My first thought when answering this problem is B because that is the closest to 6 and the longest. But then when looking at the clues it said 6 so I'll choose 6 hours.<n>```<n><n>### Hint:<n>The first time the dog runs, it has 6 minutes + 60 minutes = 66 minutes.<n>The second time the dog runs, there are 66 minutes + 6 minutes = 72 minutes.<n>The next time the dog runs, that is 72 minutes + 6 minutes.<n>Keep on doing this and you will see that the time the dog takes to run 6000 seconds.

Choices:  A: television B: attic C: corner D: they cannot clean corner and library during football match they cannot need that E: ground<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Instruction:Answer the following open-ended question** The most important task an athlete faces while playing a sport is the performance after their warm-up.<n>The warm-up has four main benefits:<n><n>* Relaxing the body into the event<n><n>* Preparing the body for the physical demands of the event<n><n>* Requiring a small amount of energy so that energy is left on the bench at the game’s finish<n><n>* Easing tension<n><n>There are a few warm-up techniques that athletes can use to ensure the proper execution of a game plan. The main three being visualization, active stretching and a pre-flight check.<n><n>In general, visualization is the practice of using the mind to picture a desired outcome, which results in mental rehearsal of that outcome. It helps to improve skills and performance, especially for complicated movements that require coordination, strength and speed.<n><n>Different types of exercise can help to improve one's physical abilities before a game or match. These include static stretch, passive stretch, active stretching and dynamic stretch. <n><n>Passive stretching involves simply stretching the joint and holding for 20-30 seconds without moving to the next position to maintain elasticity and range of motion. This technique should be limited only to when you're extremely warmed-up. Dynamic stretching involve movements that require active muscle contractions and joint movements. This involves high repetition movements, so ensure you’re properly warmed -up before going into this type of activity. <n><n>Lastly, a preflight check is done to check any possible concerns that could affect your gameplay. It is a great way to ensure that you’ve remembered everything you need and that you’ve given yourself enough time to prepare for the biggest games or contests of your life. <n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Alex has 5 green apples, 6 pears, 1 orange and 2 tangerines in his lunch box. If he takes 2 apples, he takes pear, and then takes orange  He doesn't take tangerines.  What fruit does Alex not take? A:  oranges B: tangerines C: pears D: one of the fruits<n><n>

They are amazed at this feat and decide to learn more about earth's chess playing abilities.  They then create a set of questions for the earthling to answer to show that they are worthy of their knowledge. The alien asks a couple of questions to which the human has no answer. Another question is asked which shows no correlation to the initial questions.  Thereafter, each question is asked that has at least one of the initial questions in it.  There are 10 possible questions that can be asked. The odds of this happening are 1:101000000.  Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>#### Demonstration<n><n>Example: Suppose there are 5 possible ways to answer the question above, and there are 3 questions each with at least one of the 5 possible answers.  Now suppose that the first question is about apples.  Given what we know about apples, only 2 other questions will involve apples; because apples is so specific, 3 questions have to involve it.  If this were true for every question, the odds of this happening would equal (5x3)/10000.0000.<n><n>#### Response<n><n>>![screenshot](./doc/assets/pic1.png)<n><n>### Input A chocolate milkshake costs $2.50 and a strawberry milkshake costs $5.50. His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Jame's bare feet were burned as he walked, because the sunshine had made the surface hot.  Where might he have been? Choices:  A: disneyland B: snow C: windowsill D: street E: summer<n><n>### Response:		 The answer is A<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. Choices:  A: strip club B: pocket C: millpond D: ontario E: lake or river<n><n>### Response:		<n>a)  A dam can hinder machines ability to operate. One example was when a beaver created a dam in a river near his home. The river was used for irrigation and to help power a water mill. The mill was not able to run because of the dam. The beaver was very unhappy.<n><n>### Requirements:<n>* The prompts are in the form of multiple choice question.<n>* The user can provide input of the question, and receive a multiple choice answer.<n>* Input can include letters, numbers, and punctuations.<n>* Output should be formatted using proper English and spelling.<n>* Provide two real-world examples to help illustrate the concept. (Each example must be on its own line and separated)<n><n>### Required files<n>* `main.py` : This is your entry point which should import all required modules and call the `execute()` method passing in all the arguments(prompt, choice and question_text).<n>* `choice.py` : This file contains the `choose()` method where you will need to generate a random int for the options and set `choices=[]` as shown in the sample code provided below to initialize the dictionary. You need to remove the `print('')`, that I had used to print 1 and 2 in the examples in the code.<n>* `question_text.py` : This module contains all the functions that is used in both the prompt and the choice classes.<n><n>### Sample code:<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/env python3<n># -*- coding: utf-8 -*-<n>"""<n>Sample code for a custom prompt<n>"""<n>import random<n>import time<n>from question_text import *<n>from choice import Choice<n><n><n>def execute(prompt_str, choices_lst, question_str, question_type):<n>    """<n>    Main function<n>    :param prompt_str: The prompt that is asked to the user<n>    :param choices_lst: A list of options/multiple choice that the user will choose<n>    :param question_str: Text that the message box contains<n>    :param question: Choose from 4 options<n>    """<n>    print(prompt_str)<n>    time.sleep(1)<n><n>    if question_type =='multiple':<n>        print('Choose \'(\')
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What state south of Kentucky and north of Alabama will you find people playing the fiddle? Choices:  A: alabama B: tennessee C: violin case D: music store E: bow and strings<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Output:** <n><n>### Notes:<n><n>1. <n>We're given the initial state that we have, and the new state we end with. In this case, there are a number of different ways to complete the requested goal. <n>The only restriction that really matters here is that at the "beginning state": we already had the amount of strings that we end with.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>#### Example 1:  Mary had 89.  She used 4 large stickers on the cover of her journal and the same amount of stickers on nine pages of her journal.  How many stickers does she have remaining?<n>#### Example 2:  Zach is saving his money.  His weekly income is 25.  His parents will pay him 7 dollars each Saturday.  How much money does Zach have so he can buy a book that costs 32 dollars?<n>#### Example:  Mark has fiddles, flutes, 5 goats, and 4 goats.  Fiddles play the fiddle.  Flutes are for orchestra players.  Goats have four legs. What state will you find people playing a fiddle, a violin and two flutes?<n>#### Example 4:  What state south of Kentucky and North of Alabama will you find music stores and people playing the fiddle?<n><n>### Notes on how to solve:<n>1. We can have up to two initial states but there just needs to be one final state. <n>2. Initial states and final states cannot be the same. <n>3.  There needs to be a way of incrementing and decrementing, using the symbols given.  <n>4. Additional constraints can also be added (ie. in the first one) by writing it out and making sure your code covers all possibilities.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>#### Example of use:<n>Using the following code we could create the following output.<n><n><n><n>1. A user enters an initial state (89) and a new state (59).<n>The output "50" is written because that is the remaining amount of stickers.<n><n>2. A user enters an income of 25, and is willing to receive an extra 10 as well as an additional 25 bonus income once a week.<n>The output "14" is written because that's

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Stanley had a dream that was very vivid and scary. He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		<n>I think the answer is A.<n><n>### Input<n>Input: 2/5<n>Answer: 0.40<n><n>Input: 6/7<n>Answer: 0<n><n>Input: (45/5)*(5/13)<n>Answer: 5/63<n><n>### Solution<n>```Ruby<n>a = 2/5<n>puts 0.40  # Prints 0.40, as expected<n><n>a = 6/7<n>puts 0  # Prints nothing from the shell<n><n>a = (45/5)  # Prints 9  # (45/5)[5/13] doesn't work<n><n>puts (9) * (5/13) # returns 5/63, as expected <n>```<n><n>### InputHow many stickers does Mary still have?<n>Answer: 29<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:At the end of your meal what will a waiter do? In the examples there are no commas in the string values.  If you put a comma in your input string it will throw an error.<n><n>### Input 1: Do you think I could get a job where I could work on my own? Yes if you have your own transportation no<n><n>### Input Two: Is it possible to find a job that fits my schedule? Yes if you can work less than part time hours<n><n>### Response 1:<n>```python<n>string = input(string)<n>if string == 'yes':<n>    print("yes")<n>```<n><n>## Output 1:<n><n>Yes<n><n>## Response 2:<n>```python<n>if string == "No":<n>    print("no")<n>    ```<n><n>## Output 2:<n><n>No<n><n>## Instruction<n><n>### Input1: The temperature was 36 degrees in Boston, 37 degrees in New York and 39 degrees in Dallas. What temperature was it in Seattle?<n><n>### Input2: I want to go to the movie theater.  You should check the show times.  The show times in Los Angeles were 7 pm, 8 pm and 9 pm.  What was 7 pm?  The time at 7, if you will.<n><n>### Response1:<n>```python#!/usr/bin/python3<n><n>import datetime<n><n>date = datetime.datetime.today()<n>print('Today is:', date.strftime("%Y-%m-%d"))<n><n>```<n>### Response2:<n>```python#!usr/bin/python<n><n>import datetime<n>import time<n><n>dt = datetime.datetime.now() # get current datetime<n>print(dt)<n>```

Why is that?<n>Answer:  Reading gives you an idea of what math is about. You multiply the result (9) by the number of miles per hour (60), which gives you 540 seconds, or 9 minutes.<n><n>### Answer: <n>C.

Use `processAnswer()` method in the test and write the `answer()` method that takes the inputs you create in the same test.  Use recursion or iteration to execute the method you write.  You can use multiple methods but you should have three.  The input to these methods will be one string to each method and the output will be one string to the `answer()` method and that string will contain a space-separated answer to each question.<n><n>## Note:<n>This method will return an integer with the index of the string array corresponding to the answer's index.  That means that you should use the index from the method output to get the correct answer.<n><n>## Sample Input:<n>```javascript<n>var question1 = "Mark has kangaroos";<n>var question2 = "goats.  Kangaroo";<n>var question3 = "23 kangaroes and three";<n>var question4 = "times as many goats as";<n>var question5 = "kangaroos what is ";<n>var question6 = "the total number of leg of his animal";<n>```<n><n>## Sample Output:<n>```javascript<n>"Your total number of animal has 3 of 322 legs".<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn. If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum.  He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more.   He was a very academic person and loved doing what? Choices:  A: tired feet B: gaining knowledge C: back pain D: being bored E: pondering<n><n>### Response:		<n>```Python<n>answer = ''<n><n>if 'A':<n>  answer = 'Tired feet'<n>if 'B':<n>  answer =  'Gaining knowledge'<n>if 'C':<n>  answer = "Back pain"<n>if 'D':<n>  answer = """Being bored"""<n>if 'E':<n>  answer = '''"Pondering" """<n><n>print(answer)<n>```<n><n>### Explanation:<n>```Python<n><n>response = 'Python is a great programming language'<n><n>if 'is':<n>  response2 = 'python'<n>if 'is a great':<n>  response1 =  'great'<n>if 'programming':<n>  response3 = 'programming language'<n>if 'is not':<n>  response4 = 'is it?'<n><n>print(response, response1, response2, response3, response4)<n>```<n>### Solution:<n>Answer: 'practice makes perfect'<n>### Instruction #2:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: 10 minutes equals how many seconds?<n>Answer: 10 x 60 = 600<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a statement that appropriately follows the instructions.<n><n>### Input #1:<n>In mathematics, if three times the sum of two numbers is equal to eight, what is the sum of those two numbers?<n><n>### Input 2:<n>In mathematics , if three times the sum two numbers equals eight, what is the difference of those two numbers? <n><n>### Inputs #3:<n>If three times the sum of a number equals six, and the number is three less than the result of two times the number, what is the number?<n>### Instrucation #4:<n>In mathematics, multiply four times the difference of the sum of two numbers, by the quotient of those numbers, if you divide six by the sum of the numbers. You will get one number that must be subtracted from nine multiplied by twice the difference of the sum. Now multiply five times the answer to the following problem. What is one number when you add seven to the result?<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Answer: 1) Input #1: 3(2 + x) = 8<n>x = 5<n><n>Answer: 2) 4 times  4 x

He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		None of these answers is correct. You can't see anything in a piece of wood. We cannot see what is on the inside of wood because we are not wizards. We can see what is on the outside of wood by either using a piece of mirrored glass (A), using a chisel (C), or polishing with a soft eraser with a dry cloth (B). <n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:i like to examine different things,why do books the chapters on the back Choices:  A: examine thing B: go somewhere C: knit D: read book E: see particular program<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Mary has 89 stickers<n>Answer:<n><n>    var stickers = new Array(89)<n><n>Input: Zach<n>Answer:<n><n><n>  var i = 0<n>  if (i < start){<n> <n>    i++<n>    }else{<n> <n>    if (start < end){<n> <n>    var output = start + result<n> <n>    }else{  <n> <n>    var start = result<n> <n>    var end = start -1<n> <n>    var result =  start - 1 -  end<n> <n>    }<n> <n>    }  <n> <n>  return result<n> <n>  Input: Mark<n>  Answer:<n>  var kangaroo = 0<n>  var goat = 0<n>  for ( i = 0; i < animals; i++ ) {<n>  if(animals % 2 == 0){<n> <n>      animals = animals +2<n>  }else{<n>  animals = animals -2<n>  }<n> <n>  if (i % 2 == 1){<n> <n>    kangaroo++;<n>  }else{  <n>    goat += 1  <n>  }<n>  <n>  if (start < end);<n>  var output = start + animals -1<n>  <n>  }<n><n>### Instructions:Write the output from the task.<n><n>### Input:"The sum of n and the sum of n^2 is 7n + 1"<n>  Answer:<n>    var n = n^2<n>    var output = n + 1

Universe.<n><n>### Input/Output Instruction:<n><n>### Given input/output:<n><n>- Input: Write the string "Hello".<n>- Output: Print "You are a fool."<n><n>### Given solution:<n><n>- Input:"Hello"<n>- Output: "You are a fool"<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Given string "You are a fool":<n><n>- Input: You are a fool.<n>- Output:"Hello"<n><n>### Given initial string:<n><n>- Input"Y "<n>- Output: Y o o<n><n>### Given Initial string:<n><n>- Initial Strings:<n>	- "Y "<n>	- "Yo"<n>- Input"Yo "<n>- Output: Ya<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question:<n><n>- A: "Hello" +<n>- B: "Hello"  + "<n>- C: "Hello"  -  "<n>- D: "(Hello)" + 1<n><n>### Initial string : String("Hello")<n>- Input: "Yes"<n>- Output: Ye<n><n>### Initial String: String("Yellow")<n><n>- Input: "You are a Yellow"<n>- Output: Yellow<n><n>### Input string: "You are a mammal."<n><n>- Initial String: String("You are a mamm")<n>- Input: ""<n>- Output: You are a mamm<n><n>### Input:"You are a mamm"<n><n>- Initial String:"You are a m"<n>- Input:""<n>- Output: ""<n><n>### Initial Strings<n><n>- String("You are a s")<n><n>- String(" You are a s")<n>- Input: (String("You are a s")) + "m"<n>- Output: YouAreAMamm_m<n><n>### Input "You are a m" m<n>- Initial String:String("You are a m")<n><n>- Input:"m"<n>- Output:"YouAreAMamm"<n><n>### Input"YouAreAMamm"m<n><n>- Initial String"YouAreAMamm "<n><n>- Input: m<n><n>- Output: Youareamamm<n><n>### Answer: mm  (Input: YouAreAMamm m)<n><n>### Instrumental:<n><n>-

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:The color yellow is associated with the opposite of the characteristic, what is it? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Dancing for a long time will lead you to become what? Choices:  A: sore B: intercourse C: fatigue D: become tired E: expression<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: sore<n>```<n>[ 'B', 'A', 'C', 'E', 'D' ]<n>```<n><n>Input: You have an extra hour this morning.  What is the chance you have _________ time to have your usual breakfast?<n><n>### Response<n><n><n>```<n>    'A', 'B'<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following fill in the blank question.<n><n>Fill in the blank with<n><n>- a:<n>- b:<n>-  c: <n>- d:<n>-  e:<n><n>If you are looking for the solutions then they are below<n><n>```<n>  'A', 'D', 'E', 'F', 'B'<n>  'B', 'A'<n>  'E', 'B', 'A','D'<n>  'C', 'D', 'B'<n>  <n>```<n><n>The above solution to the task is as follows:<n>```python<n>import numpy<n><n>input1 = numpy.array(['a','b']).reshape(2)<n>input2 = numpy.array(['c','d']).reshape(1,2)<n>output =  input1.copy()<n>output = output.append(input2,axis = 0)<n>output<n>```<n>Output:<n>```<n>[ 'a', 'b', 'c', 'd' ]<n>```<n>### Output:In the last two exercises and previous exercises you solved the following two-dimensional matrix problem using numpy. If you'd like to solve this problem using pure Python programming, please do so now.<n><n>### Your output should include a numpy and pure solution.<n><n>- [ ] You got this!<n><n>- [ ] I tried my best.<n><n>- [x] Nevermind! How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65. How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:What gets rid of a mundane routine? Choices:  A: sophisticated B: imprevist C: arcane D: heavenly E: new<n><n>### Response:		<n>_A_<n><n>_B_<n><n>_C_<n><n>_D_<n><n>_E_<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The word routine is describing a mundane task. The phrase _get rid of_ suggests that a thing or event is leaving or no longer present. Arcane means _unknown or obscure_. Heavenly suggests something that is not of this world and probably good. New suggests a new introduction of something pleasant (usually in contrast with something old). All of these choices except _sophisticated_ don't fit this instruction. The word sophisticated (as in sophisticated technology) suggests things that are new or in some sense advanced.<n><n>### Input and response (alternate)<n><n>Expert:A new routine in life is good.<n><n>A routine in life could be good if it were sophisticated and new or heavenly.<n><n>### Exercise:Answer this question without looking up the correct answer.<n><n>### Your Instruction:You are writing a story. Mary's mom<n>2. Mary's dog<n>3. Tom the antagonist 4. Tom and Mary<n>5. Mary's dad, mom<n>_B:_<n><n>_C:_<n><n>_D:_<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Solution<n>```python<n>picked = int(input())<n><n>if picked == 'A':<n>    print('Harbour')<n>elif picked == 'B':<n>    print('Cargo ship')<n>elif picked =='C':<n>    print('Fridge')<n>elif picked ==`C':<n>    print("Food")<n>elif picked == 'D':<n>    print('Lorry')<n>else:<n>    pass<n>```<n>### Explanation<n>```python<n>#Cargo ship<n>```<n>In this, we are using the `if` else statement. This is a way to tell whether the condition is true or false.<n><n><n>### Solution<n><n>```python<n>#Fridge<n>```<n><n>### Explanations<n><n>```python<n>```<n><n>## Solutions:

The scripts are written in `Python 3.7.0`.  They have been implemented according to http://codility.com and are based on their provided solutions.  If you are working on something similar, feel free to submit a PR.  If you have not come across this site I would highly recommend it - it is a good place to practice and develop your skills.<n><n>### The Challenges<n>Challenge | Category | Platform | Solution<n>--- | --- | --- | ---<n>Having Fun | Number Properties | Codility | [Python](https://github.com/bwilson4web/codility-python/tree/master/number_fun)<n>Most Important | Geometry | Codility | Python<n>Most Difficult | Geometry | Coda Box | Python<n>Most Challenging | Geometry | Codi Box | [Python](https/github.com/b/b/b/codility.b-geopython/codility-geopython.py?)<n>Often Overlooked | Geometry | Cody Box | Python<n>Hardest | Geometry | Cogido Box | [Python](http://github.com/drydenjameson/codility-python?focusing=git&page=1&q=cogido.cody%20#L28)<n>Odd One Out | Geometry | Coodle Box | Python<n><n>For a more in depth look at the script, please see the following links:<n>[Having Fun 1](https://github.<n>[Having Fun](https://github/bwilson-4/codility-python-number_fun.tree/master/numbers)<n><n>[Most Important 1](https://www.youtube

His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input::Tom travels 10 miles per hour. He drives 270 miles and wants to reach his destination before dark. But he can't make it. He's left with 2 options. Option 1: He keeps driving.  It will take him another 35 hours. Option 2: He has to stop. He'll be driving for 6 more hours and will still reach his destination before it gets dark. What should he do?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Tom needs to stop because he won't make it before dark.<n><n>### Input :I need 10 toothpicks. (How many needed).<n><n>`Output:

Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n><n>### Response:		 B<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Instructor note: <n>- Students may need to be directed to read all of the choices before selecting their response.<n>- I usually give each student a different set of questions when I have to give this task out.<n><n>### Other notes:<n><n>- This task can be written (one page of paper). In your response, keep it simple and straight to the point. <n>- For multiple choice questions, make sure to include each multiple choice question within it's own question.<n>- This task can also be used for students on Accelerated Reading (AR).<n><n>### Response Examples:<n><n>#### Response 1:<n><n>- Mark has an integer variable named 'kangaroosCount'. He has an integer variable named "goatsCount" and an integer variable named 'totalLeapLegs'.<n>- Initially, the variable 'totalLeapLeg' has a value of 0. After initialization, he adds three times the value of 'kangroosCount' to the value of goatsCount' and then subtracts the value of kangroosCount from the value of goats Count. This will give the value of 'totalLeapLeg'.<n>- Then if we add 'totalLeapLegCount' to 'kangroosCounter' we get the number of kangroos legs and the number of goats legs. We can then combine that by subtracting that number. Then divide that by the multiplication of three and the addition of one.<n><n>#### Example 1:<n><n>```<n><n>Mark.java<n><n>public class Mark {<n><n>    private static int kangroosCount;<n>    private static int goatsCount;<n>    private int totalLeapLegs;<n>    private int kangroosCounter = 0;<n>    private int goatsCounter = 0; <n>    public Mark(int kangroosCount, int goatsCount) {<n>        this.kangroosCount = kangroosCount ;<n>        this.goatsCount = goatsCount;<n>        totalLeapLegs = 0 ;<n>    }<n>    public void increment(int kCount) {<n>        goatsCounter = 3 * goatsCount + 1 ;<n>        kangroosCount = 3 * kangroosCount

I wish I could be a dog because they are so cute and fun and they eat anything they want. If they want to play with a tennis ball they don't care that they have to make it. They enjoy playing even more when they have to fight over the ball. I wish

If a multiple Choice question has a multiple choice responses, then choose the only corresponding choice for that question.<n><n><n>### Input Examples:<n><n>```<n>3 7  4<n>55 8    6<n>96 6        7<n>6<n>3 101 3<n>64    7<n>11 22       8<n>49 96  3    11<n>1<n>65    2<n>```<n><n>### Output Examples:<n>```<n>    A<n>    C 152<n>    B<n>    C 205<n>    B 166<n>    E 78<n><n>```<n><n>

Choices:  X: look at pictures Y: play games. Z. listen to songs. A: all of the above B. write on the e-mail C. answer e-mail<n><n>### Output Response:E: Look at pictures and play games.<n><n>### Input Output:Write a program that asks the user to enter a number from 1 to 10.  If the input is larger than or equal to 5, print the message "you have chosen correctly" to the console.  If the input less than 5, print message "you have chosen incorrectly."  Repeat until the user enters the correct number.  What is the last statement to print the message?  (Don't forget the semicolon!)<n><n>### Input/Output Answer:if(number≥5)<n><n>### Repeat Until Answer:Choose the option that describes the correct use of the  repeat until  statement. Choices:  X. The repeat until statement will repeat 3 times. Y. The repeat statement will repeat forever and  will not print again.<n><n>### Revised Answer: Y.  The repeat until statement will only repeat two times.<n><n># 3<n>### Instruction<n>Write a program that defines two variables.  Use the first variable to hold the area code of a telephone number.  Use the second variable to hold the telephone number.  Print the area code when it exists for display.  Be sure to define variable names.<n><n>### Definition<n>### Define 2 variables named phone_number and area_code<n>### Phone_number will hold the first 7 digits of a phone number. It will be 8 characters long to handle 011 prefix.<n>### Area_code will hold the area code of that first 7 digits. If the first input has no area code, then area_code will be empty.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>	Phone_number  area_code<n>	_______________|___          <n>	010056510100          <n>	|___________________|<n><n>### Output<n><n>###

What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n><n>### Response:		<n>### A: It is obvious that people might go to the state park<n>### Input:Another place people might go to during a celebration is___________.<n><n>### Response<n>```python<n>from random import randint<n><n>class GuessGame:<n>def __init__(self) -> None:<n>    self.n = 4<n>    self.m = 2<n>    self.s = randint(1, 10)<n>    self.guesses = str(list(range(0,self.n+1)))<n>    self.win = False<n>        <n>def GuessGame(){<n>    print("Guess a number between 1-4")<n>    GuessGame()<n>    return<n>}<n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    print("This game is all about your skills")<n>    print("Wanna give it a try?")<n>    print("You need to guess a number between 1 to 4")<n>    GueseGame()<n>```<n><n>### Inputs<n><n>### How many legs does the following animal have?<n><n>### A horse<n><n>### B. Cow<n><n>### C. Dog<n><n>### Answer: Choose the letter of the choice that fits in the blank. A: 4 B: 2 C: 5<n><n>### Input<n><n>### A pizza made the same size as this one would be about_________ inches thick<n><n>### Answer<n><n>```python<n>import random<n>from time import sleep<n><n>print('Welcome to the Guesstimation Game' + '\n' + 'All you need to do is guess a number')<n>sleep(2) ##Pauses for 2 seconds<n>a=input('Guess the number below.') ##Guess a random number using input<n>b = random.randrange(1,5)<n>if b in range(a,b,1): ##If b in the range of a-1<n>    print('Correct! The number you guessed is'+ str(a+1))<n>else:<n>    print('Incorrect! The number is'+ str(b))<n>   try:<n>      c = int(input("Enter number again: "))<n>    except:<n>      print('Not a number.')<n>```   <n><n>   <n>   <n>    <n>

Examples include shellfish, peanuts, milk and eggs.  An allergen can be in foods or products applied on the human body.An allergen can cause an allergist to have hives at the thought of touching crab legs.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>What year did the U.S adopt the 76 cent coin?<n><n>Answer: 1982<n><n>### Answer:<n>If your math class gives you 100 points each and you get a 97 score you would get 3 points short.<n><n>### How:<n>You get your grade to 97 points out of 100. You got 07 points more than 97. You can take away ten point from 97 because you only get one point for each. If you didn't get 100 points that would be one point too much. If you got 90 points you would only get 9 points instead of 10 points.<n><n>### Write this response on a sheet of paper:<n>**Had**: How many years ago were there were three more girls in the class than boys in your year-long math class?<n><n>**Result**: The year-long math class have 73.25 boys out of 74 girls.

Choices:  A: sew B: create art C: express yourself D: sing and dance E: write<n><n>### Response:		E and C<n><n>### Explanation:  You sing and dance - that's how you express yourself.  Art creation has to do with how you get to express yourself.  That would fall under creating art.  Sewing is something you do to create art or to express yourself creatively.  You don't just wake up one day and know how to sew.  You need to learn the skill through a teacher, you need to practice it and improve.  Writing is how you get to express your ideas.  And finally creative people have a little more than others.    <n><n><n><n>### Input:'Do you like it'?<n><n>### Demostration: <n><n>#### Input:Do you like it<n><n>#### Output:Yes<n><n>#### Why:<n><n>#### Output: No<n><n>#### Why: <n><n>

But kids may be obsessed with toys and accessories.<n>Kids may like to play video games on different stations and places.<n>They may like to use toys.<n><n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Instructions:  Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>### Input :  The person with children might have ___ (fill in any of the) plastic things in their cupboard, cabinet, their own home or the garbage dump.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Input A person with children may have lots of plastic things in cupboard, cabinet, garage, etc. so it might be A, C, D and F<n><n>### Input The person with children might own kids, who may own or play with a lot of toys.<n><n>### Output 4.  The person with children may play video games on different devices<n><n>### Instuctions:  Write a code that answers the questions below. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>### Input Betsy has three pairs of shoes in the closet.  One pair of shoes are green, one pair of shoes are blue and one pair of shoes contain orange shoes.  How many pairs of shoes can she wear on a Friday without repeating shoes? Choices: A: 0 B: 1 C: 2 D: 3 E: 4<n><n>### Response D<n><n>### Instructions: If you had to build a tree house, what steps would you have to complete in order to do so?  <n><n>### Demostration:<n>  1. First identify a tree to build.<n>  2. Find out if the tree is strong enough to support the weight.<n>  3. If so, find the length that the tree is from the ground and find the height of the tree with the ropes.<n>  4. Calculate the area of the floor.<n>  5. Calculate the weight of the rope.<n>  6. Buy the rope.<n><n>### Input : 3 + 47 - 29<n><n>### Response : 57<n><n>### Instructoin: If you had to identify numbers based on their places in a sequence, how would you  do this?  Describe each step in detail.  What kind of task is this? How  many different sequences are there for the task?<n><n>### Demosntration:<n>Step 1:  <n>  1. Obtain the sequence. <n>  2. Determine the first number in the sequence.<n><n>Step 2:<n>  1. Identify the place 3, where the second number is.<n>  2. Get the third number in the sequence<n><n>Step 3<n><n>  1. Determine the place 47<n>  2. Get 47 number in the sequence. <n><n>Step3:<n>  1. Detrmine place 29. <n>  2 Get the number in place 29<n><n>Step 4<n><n>  1. Write the number of place 3 in the sequence and subtract it from the original equation.  <n><n>Step 5<n><n>  1. Subtract the place 47 from the new value obtained at step 3.  <n><n>Step6:  <n>The remainder will be

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:If a student was about to graduate, they would no longer be attending what? Choices:  A: library B: parties C: kindergarten class D: bar E: school<n><n>### Response:		library<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>If a student was about (1) to graduate, that means that the student is (1) the age that someone should (2) graduate high school/university. When you say that someone is attending a bar, there is no sense to mention that they are not attending parties since it should be natural for someone of that specific age and level, to attend parties. It might be an unusual occurrence, but one that would occur more or less the case. Kindergarten class is an odd one in this case and might be wrong since it is a course specific for children of 5-6 years old. School could either be that you are not attending a kindergarten class or that you are attending college, and if that were the case, you would still be attending school even once you graduate.<n><n>### Check answers:A. falseB. trueC. trueD. trueE. true<n><n>### Solution 2:<n>If a student was (1) about to graduate, there is the possibility of them still having a part of the same school year, where in which case they (2) continue to attend the school. Kindergarten class and parties could be both attending school and graduation is related to the age mentioned. It is not necessary to include that someone will not attend kindergarten class, but rather just to note that they go on to another level of education, even if this case they will continue attending the same institution. Bar is the right choice, not because of it being related to alcohol, but rather for the fact that it is often an establishment that gathers adults to drink. School is once again not necessarily incorrect, although more unusual to use in a case in which graduation is considered.<n><n>### Solution3<n>A kindergarten class, as a concept is associated to be more of a child activity. Hence, it is unlikely that someone would want to go to a kindergarten class if they are already 21. This is the same for parties as they are similar child oriented activities.<n>These are not directly related to the context in which the prompt is written.<n><n>School is a misnomer as it is simply saying that the person is attending school still. One may be going to high school or a lower level while attending university.<n><n>Bar is a reasonable choice as an establishment, but still

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:Where could you put some olives to prevent them from getting nearby food wet? Choices:  A: eaten B: glassess C: jar D: pizza E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would like to respond to your need by providing multiple choice answers. <n><n>A) Eaten is not an option for putting the olives because they are food and should not be ate. The other options are not what you requested. <n><n>Therefore, I would choose : B) <n><n>Because the other options are not valid choices to keep the near by food wet since they are all ways for keeping wet or food away from the food.<n><n>### Input:`Write a method for taking an array of pets and making a new dictionary with an associative key "name" containing the list of names of the pets inside the original array`<n>### Response: I have created the following method.<n>```<n>def makeDictionary(pets):<n>    pets = [pet for pet in pets] <n>    dictionary = {}<n>    for pet in pets:<n>         dictionary.update({pet.name: pet.name})<n>    return dictionary<n>```<n>### Input:`Given 2 string, find the difference between them.`<n>### Response: <n>```<n>def difference(string1, string2):<n>     return  string1.strip() + string2.strip()<n>```<n>### Review<n>You have completed this challenge.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:James wanted to stop competing.  What might he have been feeling? Choices:  A: pressure B: death C: trying harder D: quitting E: winning or losing<n><n>### Response:		C (Trying harder)<n><n>### Reasoning:<n><n>```powershell<n>$Input= [string]"James wanted to stop competitng."<n><n>$Input |<n>Select -Property Split -OutputMode Single<n>Output:  A = 4 B = 2 C = 1 D = 0<n>```<n><n>```powershell    <n>$Input | Where-Object { $_.Split -eq 'A' } | Measure-Object -Sum<n>```<n><n>```CSV<n>Name       :A<n>Count      :1<n>Sum        :4<n>```<n><n>```csv<n>Name       :B<n>Count      :2<n>Sum        :2<n>```<n><n>```ps1<n>$Input | Where -match 'C' | Convertto-Json<n>```<n><n>```json<n>"James" : "wanted to stop competing." }"<n>```<n><n>```PS1<n>$Input | ForEach{$_.Where({$_.Contains('C')})} | Select -Unique<n>```<n><n>```Powershell<n>$Input | For-Each {"C = " + $_ | Measure-Object } | Select -Unique -Property Sum<n>```<n><n>```PowerShell<n>$Input | Select -Unique 'C' | Measure-Object | Where Count -le 1<n>```<n><n>```Input:`<n>James wanted to stop compettiing.<n>```<n><n>```Output`<n>C = 1<n>```<n>
