He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:A man was driving himself to the airport, where did he put his luggage? Choices:  A: closet B: at hotel C: sidewalk D: bus stop E: trunk<n><n>### Response:		<n>**B** <n><n>### Instructions:<n>- Each prompt, or question in the text is a multiple choice question. Write your response in the body of your response to the question in accordance with the answer choice you have selected (from A to E). Follow directions for all questions.<n>- You may reference a table, chart, graph, or formula if it is logical to do so.<n>- An appropriate response is 1 sentence long. A response is not a reiteration of questions.<n>- You should NOT write "I don't know" or some other form of expression on the test.<n>- Do not leave blank responses<n><n>### Demos<n>![Demos](./Screenshot.png)<n><n>### Input<n>Inline Code:<n>```sql<n>select * from test<n>```<n> <n>Markdown Code:<n>#### Test<n>Select *<n>from<n>test<n>```<n><n>![Demos](Screenshot.png?raw=true)<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>- [Sample answer choice](./SampleAnswerChoice.jpg?raw=true) &nbsp; &nbsp; [Sample response](./SampleResponse.png?raw=false)<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5.  His parent will pay him an extra $10 to mow the lawn.  His neighbor will pay him $7 per hour to babysit their son.  He has already saved up $65.  He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:When she went to examine the thing, what was she considering doing with it? Choices:  A: eat cake B: buy C: interests D: complex E: learn about<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>This is because in the beginning of the sentence when she was looking at it, it was an "orange thing", which is a thing she has never seen before.  I learned that if the word "thing" is at the beginning of a sentence, the person is interested or going to examine something.<n><n>### Input The word is that there's an apple and there's an orange.  What type of fruit is at least one and one half times greater than both of these?<n><n>### Response<n><n>I'm still confused about this question.  In the options, there is a green apple and a yellow one.  Why does the choice say apple?  Is there a typo that it should say orange again?<n><n>### Input A word that contains the letters _t_ and _s_ that is 7 letters long.  What letter comes next in the sequence?<n><n>### Choices:<n>A: eB: rC: sD: tE: uF: y	<n><n>### Response	<n><n>I know that when choosing vowels, you can pick either a or e.  So I'm going to think this is a vowel problem.  There are a and e in the sequence of letters, which must be either in the beginning or end of the word.  A is before e, so e must be before or after a.  So e is after a.  I'm not sure where a and e fit in the words after e though.<n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Answer: 44<n><n>Input: Zach is saving his money to buy a brand new bike that costs $100.  His weekly allowance is $5. He'll receive his allowance on Friday and he's planning on babysitting for 2 hours this Saturday after he mows the lawn.  How much more money does Zach need to earn before he can buy the bike?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Mark has kangaroos and goats.  Kangaroos have two legs and goats have four legs.  If he has 23 kangaroos and three times as many goats as kangaroos what is the total number of legs of all his animals?<n>Answer: 322<n><n>### Input:If a human wants to enjoy another human's company, where might they go? Choices:  A: place of work B: office C: friend's house D: workplace E: deep thought<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Answer: C<n><n>Input: If you want to hear the radio, you will need an:  A: alarm clock B: record player C: AM radio D: speakers E: all that and more<n><n>Answer: D<n><n>Input: Weather often does not cooperate with sports such as football because it is:  A: outdoor sport B: in sport C: canned sport D: indoor sport E: all that and maybe more<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Input: Which of these is the most recent season for baseball?  a. spring b. summer c. fall d. autumn<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n>```<n>    (a) Mary had 89stickers.  <n>    she used 3 large stickerset on the front page of the journal and 7 stickerset to each of the 6 other pages of the journal.How many stickers does Maryhave remaining?<n><n>    Solution :<n>```<n>    Let x be the No. of stickers left with Mary.Then we have 89–<n>    ( 3+7x+7*6 ) =x.<n>Now solving we get, 3+7x=x.This implies that, for finding the No. of stickerstickers left with Mary we have to take 3+7 of the 89, so answer will be<n><n>    ( 44) stickers are left.So, option (c) is the correct choice. <n><n>    (b) Zach is saving his money $5 to buy a new bike that $100.His weekly allowance is  and his parent will pay him an additional  $10 to mowe the lawn.His neighbor will pay him 7/hour to babysit son.<n>He already has $65.He'll receive his allowances  on Friday and he is planning tobabysit for 2 hours this Saturdat, then how muchmore money  Zach needs to earn before he cannot buythe bike?<n><n>    Solution:We have<n><n>    Lets sum-up the following:<n>    weekly allowances = $5<n>    $10 from parents<n>    7/hourly bribes = 14<n><n>    So Total = $29<n><n>    (c) Mark has k
